paragraph: Judan is a title given to a player who won one of the ten battles of Go. The official name of the battle is Yamato House Cup Judan-sen. It was founded in 1961. It was held by the Industrial Economics Newspaper Company and the Japan Yodo-in and Kansai Yodo-in Temple. Also known as Zunneurin ( الي Dh al-Nrain) because he was married to Muhammad's two daughters. As a child of Umayya wealthy merchants Afern Ibn Abbey al-Aas and Alwa, Usman was born. Her mother Urwa was a cousin of Prophet Muhammad. Usman's childhood was largely unknown. She was thought to have been educated in her childhood, and grew up to be a particularly read-write-long person among young people living in Macca. When Usman was a child who was gathering and carrying disguised stones mixed with other Arab Americans, she said, "wasn't wear clothes, and she had a lot of clothes, and since then her father's death has been a success."

The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

Christmas Island is an Australian federal island in the Indian Ocean. It is 2360 km northwest of Perth, Western Australia, 10 degrees 30 minutes south of 500 km south of Jakarta, Indonesia, 105 degrees 40 minutes east. It has an area of 136 km2, 63 percent of which are national parks and covered by rainforests. The population is 1,843 (2016). It became a British territory in 1888 and became an Australian territory in 1958. It is famous for a large number of aquatic crabs filling the island during the spawning season. It is not known who discovered Christmas Island. There is a record of the sea map of the Netherlands in the early 17th century, and it was seen on February 3, 1615, when the East Company of the United Kingdom of India, Thomas Mill, covered by tropical rainforest. In 1888, it became a British territory in Australia, and in 1958 it became known to fill the island during the spawning period.

According to his records, he was flown eastward from Indonesia to the Cocos Islands, arriving 28 days later. In 1886, Jack McLear discovered an inlet that could land on the island's northeastern coast, called the Flying Fish Cove. They also collected plants and animals. They first lived on the island in 1888, with John Kronez-Roth, who ruled the Cocos Islands at the time, and his younger brother Andrew Kronas-Roth. They built a settlement in Flying Fish Cove to supply timber to the Cocos Islands. Perlam Aldrich visited Christmas Island on the Egeria for about a week from September 30, 1887. The ship's natural scientist, Jackson Lister, also took part in a survey of the minerals and minerals found in Indonesia on 6 June 1888.

In Chinese Confucianism, 'chuso' is the name of a combination of 'chu,' which is an annotation of an old book in China, and 'chu,' which is an interpretation of sutras and notes. In the case of 'chu,' it is often referred to as 'chu,' which is a commentary on sutras.' Among the classics concerning Confucianism, which is an important position in ancient China, 'kyosho,' which is said to have been produced by saints, has been regarded as the most important. In Chinese Confucianism, it is common for scholars to show their interpretation in the form of annotations to the main text of sutras. An annotation directly attached to the main text of sutras is 'chu,' and in combination with this sutra and an order, it is 'chu,' which was reinterpreted from around around the time of the time of ancient China, and since then, many of the commentaries were written in the form of 'shu,' which seems to have been written in the form of 'ko,' and since then, it seems to have been written in the form of 'ko,' in the form of Chinese Confucianism.

Keibun and orders were reinterpreted as '' (also referred to as '義,' '講, '序義,' and '正義'). Yodo first flourished in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, and it was compiled as '五経正義' in the Tang Dynasty and was organized into '十三経注' in the Northern Sung Dynasty. This period was called '義' in particular. In addition to Buddhist sutras and Dokyo sutras, the term '注' was used only to refer to Confucian sutras, especially commentaries on sutras, and in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts. The form of 注 was called '一本本,' in which only the sutras were written independently, and the order was written in the form of '一本,' in which many cases of sutras, so called '義,' became a new type of study.

Kunduz (Persian: ) is a province in northeastern Afghanistan, with an area of 8081 square kilometres (24th out of 34 states), a total population of about 950,000 (7th out of 34 states), and population density of 118 people/square kilometres (5th out of 34 states). Kunduz is sometimes referred to as Kunduz, Kunduz and Kunduz. Kunduz is a smaller state than Hyogo (8401 square kilometers) in Japan. The Panji River flows from east to the north end of the state, and there is a vast oasis stretching to Takistan. The area is far beyond Oasis, and it is known as Kunduz County, Kunduz, Kunduz, Kunduz, and Kunduz. Kunduz is a region that extends from the south-eastern part of the Kunduz River to the south-eastern part of the mountain range.

The two rivers merge around the state capital Kunduz, forming an oasis to the northwest and pouring into the Amdarya River. In 1896, King Abdullahman Khan of the Dullany Tribal Union forced Seal Khan Nasser and 10,000 Pashtuns of the Guildzy Tribal Union to settle in northern Afghanistan (Torkistan) where different ethnic groups reside. Seal Khan Nassel built the town of Kundus and the port of Silhan Bandal, and founded the Spinther Cotton Company in 1921, when the Third Afghan War won, and in 1933, the company became independent from the United Kingdom of Afghanistan in 1933, when the Cotton Company became part of the state of Cotton in 1950.

Shinkai (New World) is a downtown area located in Ebisu Higashi, Namiwa Ward, Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture. There is a Tsutenkaku (temple building) near the north of the center, and there is a Junjan Yokocho in the southeast. Before it was incorporated into Osaka City in 1897, it was part of Imamiya Village, Nishinari County, and the fields and roughlands were spread. The reason for the urbanization was the 5th Inner Province Kangyo Exposition held in 1903, and it became the site of the site along with a part of Tennoji Village, Higashinari County, which is adjacent to the east. In 1907, Naoteru KATAOKA and other volunteers from the Osaka business world applied for the construction of a railway from Emisu-cho to Hamadera Temple. In 1910, 'Hankan Electric Tramway' (formerly, Hanshin Electric Tramway) was established, and the next year in 1911, the line from Emisu-cho to Ichino-cho was opened. In anticipation of the development of Emisu-cho as a terminal station, the Osaka business world planned a plan to make the site of the exposition a major entertainment center. In 1908, the Emisu intersection north-west corner of the exposition site, the Osaka City Tramway and Northern and Southern Line was opened to Umeda via Naniwa. Kyrgyz Republic (Kyrgyz Republic) (Kyrgyzstan: рг есуликас, Russian: иргиска есулика, Kyrgyzstan) is a republic in Central Asia. The former official name of the country is Kyrgyzstan and has been officially recognized as a separate name since its renaming. The capital and largest city is Biszkek. It is independent with the collapse of the Soviet Union. Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, the People's Republic of China, Tajistan, Uzbekistan and borders. The country's history spans a variety of cultures and empires. Kyrgyzstan, geographically isolated, has crossed some great civilizations as part of the Silk Road and other commercial routes. Kyrgyzstan has been inhabited and heavily ruled by several tribes. Suddenly, it was ruled by the Uighur Empire and Qatan and conquered by the Mongol Empire in the 13th century. It then regained independence, but it was invaded by the Calmuks, Manchurians, and Uzbeks. After the Russian Revolution, it became part of the Kyrgyz Republic of the Soviet Union. Following the democratization of the Soviet Union by Mikhail Gorbachev, the independent faction of Ascal Akaev was elected president of Kyrgyrzstan in 1990, and after August 31, 1991, Kyrgyr's government collapsed after the fall of political power, after the fall of the Soviet Union.

The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. Sepak takraw is a modern sport based on ballplay from the 9th century in Southeast Asia. Sepak means "kicking" in Malay and "takraw" in Thai. It is also called Tokyu. The ball is reminiscent of football or kemari (head) in terms of handling it in the 9th century, but it is also called "foot volleyball" because of its use of netcoats on the borders like tennis and volleyball. The ball is previously made of plastic (the name of the ball, and it is also referred to as "spear balls"), and the weight of the size of the ball is roughly the same as that used in the left side of the game.

The court is 13.4 m long and 6.1 m wide. It has a 155 cm high post on both sides of the center and a 76 cm long net. The center of the net is 152.4 cm high. In the case of girls, it is 10 cm low (the same size and height as badminton). The coat is depicted as a center circle, a service circle in which servers steer, an attacker and tosser enter when playing. The rules are similar to volleyball, but the following three points differ greatly. The game begins when a player in the quarter circle tos the player in the center circle and kicks the ball into the opponent's coat. When the ball hits his/her court, he/she returns the ball to the lift within three times. When the player in the quarter circle is in the center circle and the player in the center circle and puts the opponent's coat in the opponent's court. The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

A mercenary is a soldier or group who is employed for money or other interests and participates in a war without any direct interest. Since the kanji "" is not included in the daily kanji and newspaper kanji tables, it is described as a "employee soldier" in some newspapers and other reports. mercenaries still exist today, and new forms of mercenaries such as private military companies appear. Even a third party without direct interest, who is based on cause, belief, faith, etc. and whose main purpose is not money, is called a mercenary, but the distinction between them is not so strict. vocational soldiers of the National Army are employed in money, but they are not called mercenaries to fight for their own interests. Before the establishment of the state, military personnel in the modern age of the 19th century, the mercenaries were often recruited as mercenaries in the mid-19th century.

However, in the theory of the monarch, Niccolo Macavelli argued that the civil army should be created by criticizing the situation in which Florence at that time was dependent on mercenaries, and that mercenaries were actually created by the people after the establishment of a modern state, and relying on mercenaries as warlords for money without allegiance to the state was regarded as a problem, and mercenaries themselves were sometimes criticized as warlords. In the modern imperialist era, private (one type of militia) organizations that carried out irregular military actions according to their own country were used mercenaryly. Today, mercenaries are not recognized as combatants under international law, but in the conflicts in Africa, it is pointed out that de facto mercenaries employed by private military companies have been implicitly active in warfare, and in other areas such as the United States, the U.S.A.A.A.A.

After that, in the Sunnas, the Ottoman Empire, which had risen to power, was recognized as the center of the Islamic State after the destruction of the Mamluks (Mcca) and the Madenas (Medina). Because the Ottoman Empire began to cherish the Caliphate system, the hope for the Caliphate system became high again at one time, and since the Turkish Republic began to abolish the idea of a traditional Islamic State in 1924, the Islamic State of Iran has become the leader of the Islamic State of Iran.

The Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) is a concept that describes the factors determining the foreign exchange rate. The exchange rate is determined by the ratio of the purchasing power of the national currency to the foreign currency. In 1921, Swedish economist Gustav Kassel published the theory of the purchasing power of foreign exchange. The standard is the price of goods in the United States and US dollars. In theory, the purchase power parity is calculated not only for US dollars, but also for any currency. The price of goods and services represents the purchasing power of the currency, and the price of the same commodity is determined by the market where goods and services are freely traded. (One law states that the price of the same commodity is one value) The price of the same commodity is the same as that of foreign currencies in Japan. In Japan, the same currency is often used to balance the same price.

In fact, it is considered that the exchange rate is strictly in the state of the purchase power level, and the inflation and deflation of the economy by two currencies are not reflected in the exchange rate and the state of the purchase power level is maintained. The exchange rate is not affected by various factors other than the purchase power. However, it is considered that it is difficult for the state that the purchase power level is greatly separated from the purchase power level to last in the long term. According to the theory of the purchase power level, "the actual exchange rate and the purchase power level are not always the same, but it is normal to separate." In accordance with the theory of the purchase power level, there is a discussion about the dollar, "it is not a big problem because the export price based on the purchase power level is about 85 yen." However, the exchange rate is considered to be the same as that the exchange rate has not been considered in the long term. At the same time as in Japan, the Institute for Banking and Banking and Banking and Banking Research, the fact that "the actual exchange rate and the purchase power level are not always consistent, but it is normal to be separated." According to the theory of the purchase power level, the dollar, "It is not a big problem because the export price is about 85 yen because the purchase power level based on the export price is about 85 yen, but the exchange rate is not a big problem." Kinu is an animal fiber made from silkworms. It consists mainly of proteins and fibroin produced by silkworms in the body, but it is the only long fiber (filament yarn) in natural fibers because it can be taken from a single silkworm from about 800 to 1,200 meters. It has a unique luster and smooth texture, and it has been highly valued as a material (silk fabric) of clothing since ancient times. Silk made silk made from silkworms and drawn out of a few fine silk yarns and left in the form of filaments is called kinto, but on the other hand, silk is refined with alkaline chemicals (such as soap, ash, soybean, and soy, etc.) and it has been highly valued as a material (silk fabric) since ancient times. It has been referred to as silk yarn since the Meiji period, and it has been called kinto since the Meiji period.

In addition, it is divided into wild silk made from poultry silk and wild silk. The production of silk began in China around 3000 B.C. According to legend, the empress Sairyo, the Empress of the Yellow Emperor, built silk and textiles around 6000 B.C. It is said that, at least in the former Han Dynasty, the method of warming in the poultry room and the method of storing mulberry eggs was established, and the production of mulberry (Chinese version) which is famous in present-day Sichuan Province was started. In the mid-sixth century, according to "Seiminyojutsu" in the Northern Song Dynasty, it was found that the current cultivarity principle was almost established. In the Northern Song Dynasty, both tax laws were substantially changed from senna to najirui (individual silk) in 1000 B.

Outsourcing (outsourcing) or outsourcing (outsourcing) is a contract in which an external organization (such as a subsidiary, a partner company, a business contractor or a staffing company) with a high degree of expertise, etc. independent of a business process previously required within an organization or for a new business process, purchases it as a labor service. The opposite term is "insourcing" (in-house). Outsourcing includes both domestic and domestic, and the latter is said to be "choosing the function of a business that a company has and moving it outside of the country" as offshoring. There are similar business contracts, outsourcing and outsourcing and outsourcing. In addition, the National Institute of Foreign Languages' "exchange proposal" asserts that it should be called "external outsourcing." The term "outsourcing" refers to "contracting" and "contracting" as "contracting resources" and "contracting resources." The term "outsourcing" refers to the "contracting" and "contracting" of resources.

In a narrow sense, it refers to outsourcing a part of the company's business process to the outside world. In a broad sense, it refers to procuring resources and services that are necessary for the company's business from the outside. It is useful for outsourcing parties to concentrate on their core business and outsource other operations (efficiencies or specializations if they are used externally) to the outside world. Efficient operations can be achieved by freeing themselves from multi-disciplinary professional development. It is also called IT outsourcing because there are no dedicated assets or operations departments within the company and they are not provided as services. In the information industry, it is also called IT outsourcing, and there are resources provision services such as hardware software and network products, maintenance and management services, as well as the construction of applications. In addition, it is often referred to as multi-souring (multi-souring) industries, which are often referred to as outsourcing companies.

The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

At first, the relationship between the two counties was opposite to the current one, and the present Mogami-gun belonged to Murayama-gun County. As in the early modern period, the two counties were replaced, and as in the present day, the north became Mogami-gun and the south became Murayama-gun. These counties were later called Mogami-gun and local villages. However, in the present day, it is referred to as Mogami-gun and Mogami-gun in the Edo period, which were called Mogami-gun or Mogami-gun in the Edo period.

The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

The Doha Agreement, signed on February 29, 2020 between Taliban and the United States of America in Doha, agreed to a peace treaty in Afghanistan. The official name is Agreement for Bringing Peace to Afghanistan. The agreement, which included the gradual withdrawal of the U.S. Forces stationed in Afghanistan and the commencement of negotiations between the Afghan people, was implemented and the Afghanistan conflict ended for about 20 years. However, the agreement, which was concluded without the involvement of the Afghan government, led experts to "one of the most disgraceful diplomatic negotiations ever made" and led to the full resurrection of the Taliban. There are also criticisms that the U.S. reduced the number of troops stationed within thirteen days to five (500,000 to 000) and closed the military base by the end of 2021.

The Afghan government has shown difficulty with the release of senior commanders of the highly threatened Taliban, and proposed a conditional release of 1,500 people. After two or three turns, the Taliban rejected the proposal and ended negotiations. In May, President Ashraf Ganny concluded a power-sharing agreement with his political opponent Abdullah Abdullah as the negotiator for the deal. The Afghan government announced the release of up to 2,000 Taliban by August. By September, the Afghan government released 5,100 people and the Taliban released 1,000 people. In September, Afghan government and Taliban's first peace talks were held, but the Afghan government, on the other hand, held the first peace negotiations between Taliban and Abdulah Abdullah and Abdulah Abdullah, despite the fact that they were in charge of negotiating the deal. The Afghan government announced the release of up to 2,000 people from Taliban by August 500.

The Computer Entertainment Rating Organization, a specified non-profit corporation in Japan that formulates and examines the ethical provisions of expressions targeting home game software and some personal computer games. In 2002, there was a trend of Japanese society, which was considered to be a strong and bad thing to play. Therefore, the gaming industry did not need a rating system, but was created to clarify the public's attitude. Unlike IARC, which is not a member of the IARC (International Association of Age Assessments), the examination is only in Japan for a fee. Also, in the case of IARC in Japan, it was established in June 2003 as a means of obtaining a hard-to-respond CERO, which would be required to be a hard-to-respond entity. In the case of IARC, the game industry was established in order to establish a system that would not require a rating system, and the industry side of the public to clarify its attitude to the public. The International Association for Age Assessment (IARC) is not a member of the International Association of Age Assessment (IARC). In addition, in the case of Japan, it was established in June 2003 as a company that was established in order to acquire a hard-to-response basis for its activities.

Prior to the establishment of CERO, Sony Computer Entertainment (PlayStation · PlayStation 2), Sega (Dreamcast), Microsoft (Xbox) and Nintendo (Nintendo Game Cube Game Boy Advance) were reviewed by each console manufacturer (licensor) based on their own criteria, but there were also differences in the criteria of the examination between SCE · Sega · Microsoft · Nintendo, and in some cases it was forced to modify the contents. The purpose was to unify the standards of each manufacturer and respond to criticism of game software at the industry group level, as well as to complement ratings that were later than other countries. CERO has a membership system, in which individuals and groups who agreed with the purpose of the CERO are endorsed and endorsed by the members of the competition, and in some cases, members of the group who received support from the members of the group were forced to participate in the screening process.

A bicircular cone, or bicircular cone, or bicircular cone, is a three-dimensional figure in which two joint (direct) cones are pasted together at the bottom of each other. The surface of the equatorial plane is called the equatorial plane. The equatorial surface is not a surface of the bicircular cone (in the sense that the bottom is the surface of the cone). It can also be defined as a rotating body with a rotational axis at the bottom of the biangular triangle, or a rotational axis with a diagonal diagonal in the form of a rhombic cone. The familiar bicyclic cone has a crutch. The equatorial cone is a type of bidirectional cone. The equatorial cone has a biangular cone that has a biangular cone shape. The equatorial cone is not a surface of the biangular cone (as in the sense that the bottom is the face of the cone). The bigonal cone is a rotating body with a diagonal axis at the bottom of the second triangular triangle, or a rotational cone with a diagonal diagonal axis.

The rating is an estimate of how many percent of TV receiver-owned households in the area watched a particular TV program, and it is one indicator. In the past, the reading rate was based on data obtained from a dedicated device connected to a TV installed in a monitor household. Depending on the region and the survey, some surveys are conducted by diary-type questionnaires. In the Showa period, TVs were expensive and had a lot of volume due to the influence of the Brown tube, and it was common for households to have only one or more of them even if they owned a television receiver. It was thought that one TV was only looking at which channels it was receiving, so that the rating rate was the same as that of other TVs in the period. As a result, the number of people who watched TVs became critics of multiple TVs.

As of 2020, in-house metrics used by each TV station in Japan have been shifted to individual ratings. The rate of viewership is not a percentage of all households to be surveyed, but rather a percentage of households to be surveyed. For example, if 100 households were subject to TV rating measurements, say, "one household was wearing TV." However, in the case of "the remaining 99 households were turning off televisions", the rate of viewing a program that was watched by one household was 1 percent. It is not 100 percent. When measuring the percentage of households that were on board, the percentage of each station is called the percentage of households to watch a program. The significance of surveying the rating rate is largely divided into the following: the 1970s and the 90s, when video decks of VHS became more popular in the 2000's and after the 2000's, the hard disks became popularized.

Wheat is a perennial plant belonging to the genus Triticum (scientific name: Triticum aestivum), but in a broad sense refers to the whole plant of the genus Triticum (scientific name: Triticum compactum) and durum durum (scientific name: Triticum durum). It is one of the three largest grains in the world and is a major ingredient in wheat, bread, noodles, and confectionery. Tokyo-fu was a prefectural government in Japan. The prefectural office was located in Yuraku-cho, Yodo-cho Ward, Tokyo City. Edo-fu was established in Edo, Musashi Province in 1868 and changed its name to Tokyo-fu shortly after that, but it was abolished due to Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) in 1871, and Tokyo-fu was established again in the form of including surrounding areas. In 1880, the Izu Islands and the Ogasawara Islands were incorporated, and in 1889, Tokyo City consisting of 15 wards was established. In addition, Mitama County was transferred from Kanagawa Prefecture to Tokyo. In 1932, the merger of the surrounding towns and villages became Tokyo City in the same year as Tokyo City, and on May 25, 1943, the same year, the military administration of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was established.

The Edo prefectural government was renamed 'Chinsho-fu' by the Tokyo prefectural government on July 17 of the same year, and the name of Edo prefectural government was changed to 'Tokyo' instead of 'Tokei,' and the name of the post was 'Tokei.' On August 17, the Tokyo prefectural office was established, and on September 2 of the same year, the Tokyo prefectural government system was promulgated and the office was transferred from the City Court to the prefectural government. On September 8, 1869, the era name was changed to Meiji. On March 16, 1869, the ward was divided into wards with 10,000 people living in Suzakunai-cho as 'Ku,' and the ward was divided into 'Ku Ward,' and the ward was designated as 'the ward of the ward,' and on the second day of the same year, 'the ward of the ward' and 'the ward of the ward' was designated as 'the wards and wards of the wards of the wards' and 'the wards of the wards and wards of the wards of the wards,' and 'the wards and wards of the wards of the wards of the wards and wards of the wards of the wards and wards of the wards of the wards of the wards.

The Goal dynasty (Persian: يا Ghryān) was an Islamic dynasty in present-day Afghanistan that invaded northern India and established the first stable rule of Muslims in India (from around the early 11th century to 1215). It was also described as the Gour dynasty and the Champsabani dynasty, and the royal family was called the Champsab family. The Champsabani people, led by the Champsab family, lived in the Gole region (also known as the Mandesh) east of Herat, in central Afghanistan, upstream of the Harry River, and spoke Iranian languages. The name of the dynasty occurred because they were called the Goal or Goul people from their place name. It is not known about the origins of the royal line, but it was summarized in the postmortem period, and the Champsabani people who lived in the Gole region of the mountainous region (also known as the Gole or Mandesh) east of the Harry River in the middle of present-day Afghanistan.

In the 12th century, King Kutubuddin, a member of the royal family, was poisoned when he escaped to Gazna's court in the struggles of his brothers, and after this incident, he was captured and imprisoned by Gazna's supporters for a time, and Gazna's army was captured, and the Gazna and Gazna's conflicts were deepened. In 1150, Alāud-Dnuusyna II, a member of the royal family, was killed in Gazna's court.

The Sovereign Base Areas of Akrotiri and Dhekelia (Greek: Sovereign Base Areas of Akrotiri and Dhekelia) was a region on the island of Cyprus that constitutes the British Overseas Territory and is governed by the British. When Cypriot status shifted from the British Empire's colony to an independent republic within the Commonwealth, it was decided that the United Kingdom would continue to retain the base, as Cyprus was strategically based in the Mediterranean. The base was divided into two regions, one of which was the Acrotir (Agrotur) of the British Overseas Territory, and the other was the Greek Air Force Base (Acrotian: Agrotur) of the United Kingdom of America (Acrotian: ωω     ,          ,       ,          ,                   ,

The British wanted to leave a sovereign region on the island of Cyprus in order to secure military bases, such as the Air Force's Acrotili base and the Army garrison. However, the importance of this area to the British was that it was located at the eastern end of the Mediterranean Sea, close to the Suez Canal and the Middle East, that the Air Force base could be used as an airfield for military use, and that it could be used for comprehensive training. In 1974, Turkey invaded northern Cyprus and established the internationally-certified North Cyprus-Turkish Republic. However, this incident did not affect the position of the British base, and the British were not involved in the battle. The Greek inhabitants of Proxis who escaped from the Turkish invasion were allowed to pass through the Greek-occupied area, and until 1974 the southern part of the province of Paradise, where the city of Paradise was protected by a small military base.

The Persian language (Persian: ا fsi ) is a language spoken in the Middle East centered on Iran. It is also called the Persian, Farshei, and Pearlsee languages. It is linguistically classified as an Indo-European-Indo-Iranian-Iranian language group. Persian has been used mainly in the Iranian plateau from the ancient Persian Empire to the present day, and can be traced back to very ancient times by literature. However, the current Persian language borrows a great deal from Arabic, and its form is considerably different from the ancient Persian name, "ا farsee", which is the name of the Persian language, and is sometimes referred to as "Persian" or "persian".

Historically, the name "Dallie" has also been used, but now it generally refers to the Persian language of Afghanistan. In Afghanistan, "Dallie" was designated as the official language name in 1958. Prior to that, local Persian speakers called their language "Falcy" and externally referred to as "Afghan-Persian." Tajikistan refers to "Tajik" as the official language. It is also spoken in parts of Iran, Tajikistan, Afghanistan and Uzbekistan, Russia, Caucasus, Bahrain, Iraq. The native language is said to be more than 46 million people. In Iran and Tajikistan, the only official language that can be called "Afghan-Persian." Tajik is the official language in Tajikistan. In Iran, Tajikistan, "Tajik" is sometimes referred to as the official language.

Islamism (also known as Islamism or Islamism) is a term used to refer to the political and social movements and ideological tide that seek to realize a system in which Islamic principles are governed as norms. The term "political Islam" is also used among Western researchers, and the term "Islamismist" is used in Japan, where the term "Islamic Revivalism" is used mainly to describe the term "Islamicism" in Japan.

Although there are several historical examples of the Islamic State Construction Movement as a criticism of the regime that is believed to have left the Islamic State, the term Islamicism is used to refer to a political movement that emerged from the trend of Islamic revival in modern times, especially among such movements. Since the 1980s, the term "Islamic Principleism" has been used to refer to a political movement that corresponds to Islamism in the non-Islamic region, and it has been established through mass media in Japan. However, among Islamic researchers, there have been claims that it is problematic to apply the concept of Principleism to Islam in the first place, and the term "Principleism" has been used as a word that refers to a particularly sharp, combative group among Islamism, and therefore, it is not easy to see that Islamism has become popular in Japan. However, the term "Islamicism" has not been used as an easy-to-to-use term.

Jacques Cartier (31 December 1491 – 1 September 1557) was a Breton explorer and invader from San Maro, Brittany, France, who was the first European to reach the Gulf of St. Lawrence and the banks of the St. Lawrence River, and was known as "Canada" in the words of the Iroquois. He made three expeditions to North America, reaching the mouth of Prince Edward Island and St. Lawrence, landing in what is now Quebec, and later establishing the basis for Canadian possession by France. Cartier was born in 1491 in San Maro, a port town in the northwest of the Duchy of Brittany.

In 1532, two years after the Duchy of Brittany's alliance with France, in 1534, Cartier was introduced to France by Jean Le Veneur, bishop of San Maro and monastery of Mont Saint Michele. François had already sent Giovanni da Verrazzano to the North American continent in 1524 to explore the coast from present-day South Carolina to Newfoundland, but he ordered Cartier to explore the rest of the region because there was no significant discovery in the expedition. The first expedition continued with the French king's voyage to New France in February 1534, when he sailed to Newfoundland.

The Guilzai Tribal Union (Ghilzai) is one of the Pashtune Tribal Unions, sometimes referred to as the Guildsay Tribal Union. The Guildsei Tribal Union is one of the two Pashtune Tribal Unions. It consists of the eastern Afghanistann tribes centered in Gazney, Afghanistan. The Guildsei Tribal Union established the Hortakie dynasty in the 18th century. It is said that the tribes were twice as large as the Dullerney Tribal Union, another tribal coalition. The Guildsays were associated with the Turkish Harajus, who lived in Gazney in the 7th and 10th centuries, and there is a theory that the Pashtune was the source of the Pashtune in the 16th century.

A magazine () is a type of publication that is a serial publication and a periodical publication. It exists not only in general circulation of entertainment magazines including comics and novels, but also in various genres including media, comprehensive magazines containing them, various hobby magazines and specialized magazines, academic research magazines and government journals. In a broad sense, magazines are two major sources of information, including books and books centered on books. The characteristics of magazines are that they are not comparable to daily newspapers in terms of quick news, but are superior to books and books. They are easier to publish than books and books, and they are used to provide information and entertainment information in narrow specialized fields that are difficult to publish as books and books. The magazines and magazines are treated as intermediate being used as magazines and magazines, and the magazines are also called "discontinuation" because of their characteristics.

Some magazines have continued to be published in large numbers for a long time, while others have been discontinued due to changes in trends and the recession of publications, and some magazines have shifted to online distribution instead of paper. In Japanese magazines, the standard of number of issues differed depending on the magazines in the past, and some magazines have appeared to indicate the number of issues several months ahead of the actual release date, causing confusion among bookstores and readers. Therefore, due to the voluntary rules established by the Japan Journal Association in November 1986, "remarks on magazine creation," it was decided that the number of days and issues prior to the release date of the magazine could be added. As a result, many magazines are listed ahead of the release date in order to produce the novelty of the magazine. The same number can be written as the release date. Usually, L-mm/dd is displayed under the actual release date of the magazine code, and it is not always available until the end of the following year. However, it is not always available until the next day.

Asset freezing is the prohibition or limitation of moving or disposing of assets. Specifically, it is prohibited to order banks to withdraw money from their bank accounts or send money to other accounts, or to change the registration of land. When a company goes bankrupt, the court may order the asset to be frozen so that creditors and others do not suffer any disadvantages. The court may also order the asset to be frozen for assets that have been confirmed to be subject to enforcement. Taxation agencies may also take the procedure of freezing assets for the assets of those who are delinquent in taxes. The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

The Dutch East India Company (Dutch: Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie, officially the Allied East India Company; Dutch: Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie, or VOC) was founded in the Netherlands on March 20, 1602 and is said to be the world's first company. The company was not only a commercial entity, but also an imperial company granted various kinds of privileges, such as treaty concluding rights, warfare rights, colonial management rights, and other privileges to the east of the Good Hope peak. It was a pioneer of imperialism. It was engaged in trade and colonization in Asia and established a major maritime empire. The capital is called about 6.5 million guilders, and the executive association is called a 17-person association. The Bank of the same country also participated in the branch office of Amsterdam, which was set up in the late 18th century 1899, when it was placed on the brink of war in Spain.

In the midst of this, the Netherlands had to develop its own Asian routes and fight against Spain (and the annexed Portugal). From 1595 to 1597, when the Netherlands made a successful round trip to and from Banten, Java, several companies made full-scale transactions with Southeast Asia. However, due to multiple merchants' attempts to expand into Southeast Asia, the price of the purchase of spices in Southeast Asia increased, and the price of the sale was only falling due to the price competition between the trading companies in the Netherlands, leaving fears for winning the economic competition with other countries. Furthermore, the establishment of the British East India Company in 1600 deepened this concern. The Central Holland politician Ordenbarnefelt established a coalition of several merchants in order to counteract foreign movements, and established the East Company of India, as well as the six Indian companies, each of which were based in the Kingdom of Amsterdam.

Oceania is a continent located in Oceania in the southern hemisphere of the Earth. Its area is the smallest of the six continents. It is entirely Australian, facing the Pacific Ocean in the east, the Indian Ocean in the west and south, and the Alaphra Sea in the north. It is sometimes abbreviated as the "Australia Continent" or the "Australia Continent" and "Australia Continent." The present Australian continent is located near the mid-latency high-pressure zone, especially in winter (around July), so it is always in a dry climate. In addition, the Oita Minamata Mountains are located in the easternmost part of the continent, where moisture-containing air from the Pacific Ocean rains a large amount of water and loses moisture. The western part of the continent is blown away by dry winds, and the central part of the continent is dry, resulting in a relatively dry climate (about 5 percent of the climate), and the western part of the region where it is located.

Although there are mountains such as the Oita Minamata Mountains, it is a flat continent that is eroded as a whole, and the highest peak of Australia is the 2,228-meter-high Kogiosco in the Oita Minamata Mountains (the ancient mountain range), and there is a very old and stable Australian trench in the western part of the continent. In addition, some of the rocks formed more than two billion years ago, such as the Pilbarakraton. The Pacific Ocean's reef "Antarctic Barrier Reef" and the erosion-shaped Uru (a.k.a. Aired's Rock) are said to have been isolated from the Gondwana continent. The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

Mont Blanc (French: Monte Bianco) is the highest peak in the European Alps, located on the border between France and Italy. It is 4807.81 m above sea level. In Europe, it is second to several mountains belonging to the Russian territory of the Caucasus Mountains near Asia (such as Mount Elbrus) and is the highest peak in Western Europe. Mont in French means "mountain" and Blanc means "white", meaning "white mountain". In Italy, it is also called Monte Bianco, meaning "white mountain" in Italy. Also, the name La Dame Blanche, which means "white woman", is also known as La Dame Blanche, the French name for "white woman" and it is also known as La Dame Blanche.

The International Monetary Fund (French: едународнй валтнй онд онд )Fondo Monetario Internacional (Spanish:  ال اللي)International Monetary Fund (IMF) is one of the specialized institutions of the United Nations (United Nations) which was set up to stabilize the international finance and exchange market. As of 2018, there are 189 member states. As a result, the international Monetary Fund (Arabic:  ال اللي ) International Monetary Fund (IMF) is an international financial and foreign exchange rate stabilization organization.

This led to the establishment of an international body to coordinate and coordinate international finance and exchange between countries as part of the post-war vision of the Allies. Both the plan of the United Kingdom's John Maynard Keynes and the plan of Harry White in the United States were submitted, but the final organization became similar to that of White. In July 1947, in Breton Woods, New Hampshire, the United States, the United Nations "Financial and Fiscal Conference" was held to stabilize international finance and exchange markets. The Breton Woods Agreement, which was signed at the meeting, led to the establishment of a stable monetary system as part of the Second World War, led to the establishment of the International Monetary Fund in 1945. On the other hand, the Bank of the United States of America and the United States of America's Breton Woods, New Hampshire.

Waziristan (Urdu: ا ) is a region in the FATA in the northwestern part of Pakistan. It is approximately 11,585 km2 in area. It is often written as Wajiristan in Japanese. It is a rough mountainous area, located on the border, and is located in the west of Paktiker, Afghanistan. It is close to Peshawar, and in the east there is Caibal Paktunkwa. Waziristan was a tribal area that was beyond the control of the British Indian Empire until 1893, when Muslim tribes invaded the empire frequently from Wazilis Turn, and from 60 to 1945, it was dispatched to the United Kingdom several times during the period from 1945 to 1919, when the troops were oppressed and mobilized.

The tribes of Wazilizturn are governed only by men, mainly the elders who make up the "Great Council" (Roya Zirga), and women are kept away not only from social activities but also from housework. The tribe's cliques have been firmly maintained by the "Group Responsibility Act" of the " Frontier Crime Regulations" applied to Wazilis Turn. It has been known for its valiant climate in which blood conflicts have never ceased. The Darwesh Khel people, who belong to the Wazil people centered in the town of Miranshah, live in Pakistan. The population is approximately 360,000 (as estimated in 1988) and the area is 4,473 km2. Most of the population lives in the fallen villages between the fortified mountains. The state of Afghanistan and the borders of Wazilisturn are free to enter the borders of Pakistan, and the majority of the population is not limited to the territory of Pakistan.

The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

Oceania is one of the six major provinces. Oceania refers to the continents and islands on the Pacific Ocean, and in general interpretation refers to 16 countries (Australia, Kiribati, Cook Islands, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Tonga, Nauru, Niue, New Zealand, Vanuatu Republic, Papua New Guinea, Palau Republic, Fiji, Marshall Islands Republic, and the Nesian Federation), and 25 protected territories (see a few of the right), all of which refer to land on the Pacific Ocean; in this case, Japan, Taiwan, the Philippines, Indonesia, the Pagosian Islands, the Pagosian Islands, the Republic of Naurus, the Republic of New Zealand, the Republic of Palau, Fiji, the Republic of Marshall Islands, and the Nesian Federation of the Republic of the Republic of the Pacific Ocean.

As of 2018, the population of Oceania is approximately 4.1.5 million. Oceania is generally divided into four regions: Australia, Melanesia, Micronesia, and Polynesia. The names of the three regions of Melanesia, Micronesia, and Polynesia begin with European explorers. In 1756, French explorer Charles de Bros began using the Greek word "Polynesia Note 1" as a generic term for all islands in the Pacific. Later, French explorer Jules Bastian Cesar Dumonturville divided the island of Oceania into three districts, and in 1756, the Society of Geography of Paris introduced the term "Ocean archipelago" (European archipelago) as an archipelago.

Summer time note 1] (summer time note 3) or daylight saving time (DST note 4) is a time system, or time system, in which clocks are made to make more effective use of the bright hours of the day during the summer, during which daytime becomes longer throughout the year. In typical practice, clocks are moved to one hour in spring, and clocks are turned back to one hour in autumn, and then returned to the standard time. As a result, there are 23 days in the spring and 25 days in the autumn. The time of the day is saved by a candlelight scholar in order to reduce the time of daylight. In order to save time for the first time in seventeen years, a scholar in France has proposed a way to save time.

In 1895, New Zealand entomologist and astronomer George Hudson proposed a two-hour clock change every spring to the Wellington Philosophical Society. In 1907, William Willett, a British resident, proposed a similar idea as a way to save energy, but failed to implement it. In 1908, the world's first summer time was introduced at Port Arthur, Ontario, Canada. The first nationwide time was between the German Empire and the Austro-Hungarian Empire, which began on April 30, 1916 to reduce coal consumption during World War I. Since then, summer time has been held many times in many countries, especially after the oil crisis in the 1970s. In the vicinity of the equator, there has not been much variation in the time between the sun and the sun. In general, there is not much variation in the time between time and time spent in Australia and other parts of the world.

The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

Buddhism (old name: Bukkyo) is one of the three major religions in the world that Gotama Siddharta (Shakyamuni) advocated in the middle of the Ganges River in the northern part of India about 2,500 years ago (around the 5th century BC) and spread all over the world. Buddhism, along with Christianity and Islam, is one of the three major religions of the world. Buddhism is a religion of Buddha (Buddha, awakens, awakens to truth, awakens) and Buddha (Nyorai). In particular, it emphasizes the process of attaining enlightenment by awakening oneself (dharma) and finally, "the self that adheres to oneself is intangible" (muga) and seeks liberation from the bundle of hardship (discipline), and it is said that Buddhism has become one of the highest quality cultural properties in Kyoto Prefecture.

The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

Mutawa (Arabic: مي , Arabic: مي ) is an organization that provides educational guidance to the public from an ethical and moral position in Islamic values for the purpose of prohibiting acts considered to be vicious in Islam and advocating for the conduct of virtue. It is interpreted as a religious police in the West. Mutawa exists in Islamic countries such as Saudi Arabia, Iran, Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Pakistan, Egypt, Yemen, Nigeria, northern Nigeria, and Malaysia. Organizations vary in size and social treatment from country to country, from national institutions to religious entities to private organizations. It was originally a volunteer organization that teaches people to live according to the teachings of Islam, and as well as the progress of civilization and social changes that have emerged have been interpreted as interpreted by Muslims. However, there has been an increasing amount of criticism from other countries.

In Saudi Arabia, it is referred to as the Committee on Punishment and Punishment, and it has a very strong social influence. Although it has no judicial police or jurisdiction, its activities involve police officers, arrests by police at the request of the commissioners, criminal trials by the charges of the committee, and so on. Before the 1990s, it was essentially a volunteer organization that teaches life, but as Western culture enters the modern era, it exhibits extreme refusal and severe crackdown on it. Overseas, it has been criticized as a human rights violation organization, and in recent years, due to growing dissatisfaction in the country. It has been actively active during the Taliban administration, but it has been abolished due to the invasion of Afghanistan. However, it has been reorganized in 2003, and it continues to continue to reinvigorate Islam in recent years.

The Japan Art Theatre Guild (ATG) was a Japanese film company that was active from 1961 to the 1980s. It was absorbed and merged into Toho on November 1, 2018. It produced and distributed non-commercialistic works of art that differed from other film companies and greatly influenced the history of Japanese films. In the latter half of the year, it actively adopted young directors and fostered people who would later become responsible for the Japanese film industry. ATG published the film magazine Art Theatre for each public film. We were sold only at the screening hall, consisting of complete film scenarios and film reviews. ATG was established with the aim of delivering high-quality art films to more people. It was not possible to pay for the yearly fee, but it was the first time for young people to watch films in Japan. At the time, it was a major topic of interest for young people in the early 1970s and early 1970s. It was the most important culture in Japan.

Supported by this situation and the membership system, it became possible to produce popular films that had a great influence on young people at the time, such as "Shinjuku thief diary" by Hiroshi OSHIMA, "Hatsukoi Hellenge," and Toshio MATSUMOTO's "Sinema no Misasagi" by Toshio MATSUMOTO. The activities of ATG can be roughly divided into the first period, which mainly distributed foreign films, the second period, which actively adopted young directors at low budgets, and the third period. Asian films in the 1950s, Poles and the influence of France and Nouvervag, led to an increased interest in art films in Japan. In 1957, young filmmakers such as Kawara and Hahito formed a group called "Sinema 57" and produced films. At that time, the filmmakers of Towa's vice president, Yoshitaka Yoshikawa, who was aiming to become the vice president of Towa's films at the time, aimed to actively adopt young directors in the third period. The film theaters and film festivals were held at the time.

A quiet sea (Latin: Mare Tranquillitatis) is one of the lunar seas on the surface of the moon. It is equivalent to a rabbit's face in the case of a roaring rabbit on the moon. It is also the place where the Apollo 11 lunar lander landed. The first place for mankind to land on July 20, 1969 was named a "silent base" with 0.7 degrees latitude and 23.5 degrees longitude. The three small craters nearby were named "Armstrong", "Ordrin" and "Collins" respectively, after three astronauts from Apollo 11. The lunar surface rover, launched before Apollo in February 1965, landed on July 20, 1969, and landed at the site of the Moon's latitude and the Moon's longitude of 23.5 degrees.

The term "soundtrack" refers to the part of the film that contains the sound on the film. The term "soundtrack" derived from the film terminology may refer to an album containing "drama, film, television games, anime, commercial songs" and other "attendant music" or "accompanied music." It is often referred to as a Santra, but it is sometimes referred to as an OST (original soundtrack) (original soundtrack) and the soundtrack is a technical term that refers to a sound track that is independently provided as an image comma in the longitudinal direction of the film. The first film to be released using this method, which was released in 1926, has a new type of "optical soundtrack" that was originally used to describe the film's longitudinal direction.

The optical and magnetic forms are old, magnetic ones are new. The stereos are old, of course, and stereos appear later. The world's first stereo film was Fantasia, released in 1940, with another optically four-track audio-recorded film (left, middle, and right speakers and a synchronized signal) and screened. For business purposes, the single-type simultaneous recording (a method of recording on a film without using a separate recording machine) with a focus on news coverage, many magnetic forms were used (e.g., a Canon 16mm Scoop) and the soundtrack for 8mm films was magnetic, most of which were commonly used (note: 8mm optical recordings are also used in commercially available prints, but the optical recordings are used at the same time).

The characters who appeared were the same, but the story was positioned as a parallel world with a big difference, and there was no contact at all with the works produced in Japan. The scene conversion “Emblem Turn” has become a healthy cell painting in the film, but it is also called “Emblem Turn” because it is a scene that has been used for many times in the past four million years.

A stove is a device that generates heat by burning fuel. The origin of the word Stove in English is "warmroom", "drying room" and "warm room", which used to refer to a skewer stove, which has been used since the Middle Ages. It is structurally roughly classified into three types: radiant, convection, and fireplace. In American English, "stove" is sometimes referred to as "heating/cooking" or "cooker" and in British English as "heating/cooking only" is sometimes referred to as "cooker." In Japanese, the term "stove furnace" meaning originally portable heat source is sometimes referred to as "heating utensils." In addition to heating utensils, portable cooking stoves used for infants such as camping and climbing, can be used as cooking stoves, which are generally referred to as "heating stoves" or "cooking stoves" or cooking utensils.S.S.

In Japan, the term "stove" is generally used to describe the use of heating utensils, but in Japan, it is said that kamado was often used even after stoves were imported from outside Japan during the Meiji period due to the use of fireplaces and hearths for heating, and because Japanese gas equipment manufacturers did not use the name of stoves reminiscent of skewers and coal in cooking utensils. Before heating stoves became popular in ordinary households, coal ranges imported for cooking were used in some Western-style buildings, and some of them were called stoves in the name of products overseas in Japan. According to the history of "heating utensils," they were actually designed to be used for cooking pots on top of utensils, so that they could be used for cooking, for example, for cooking pots for a long time.

Sir Marc Aurel Stein (November 26, 1862 – October 26, 1943) was a Hungarian-born British archaeologist and orientalist who studied at the University of Vienna, Leipzig, the University of Tübingen, the University of Oxford and the University of London. In 1888, he was named Stein Márk Aurél (tin mrk urel).

In 1906, he conducted a second expedition, bringing back so-called Buddhist paintings, Buddhist scriptures, and ancient documents. In 1909, he was awarded a gold medal by the Royal Geographical Society for his achievements in exploration and archaeological research in Central Asia. In 1910, he was awarded the Coordination of the Indian Empire (C.I.E.) and in 1912 the King of the Indian Empire (Kinght Commander of the Indian Empire). A live broadcast is the transmission of a program from a studio or a broadcast site at the same time without pre-recording/recording (i.e. recording) the broadcast material. It may also be used for broadcasting program content on an Internet distribution (e.g., Internet radio) that is not a narrow broadcast (e.g., Nico Nico Live Broadcasting), but it may be called 'live broadcast' or 'live streaming'. The live broadcast is performed on both television and radio. The types of programs performed by the live broadcaster are mainly news, weather forecasts, and sports broadcasts requiring the promptness and accuracy of information. In the case of a variety of shows or votes, some live broadcasts may be made at the same time (e.g., Nico Nico Nico Live Broadcasting). The live broadcast may be called 'live broadcast' (e.g., live streaming) or 'live streaming' (e.g., live streaming). The live broadcast may be performed on TV or radio.

Also, in the following cases, the same record of the live broadcast program may be performed in advance and it may be broadcast at a different time, and it is called 'recorded broadcast' and 'recorded relay.' In the case of the shooting format as described above, it is very difficult for ordinary viewers and listeners to distinguish between live broadcasts and recorded broadcasts without notifying that they are live broadcasts in the program, but it can be understood by the presence or absence of a response to the subtitle supermarket of the premature broadcast system (which sends forecasts and announcements based on accumulation data such as input to a computer, packet communication, etc.) and sudden accidents such as disasters (even though the home of the viewer is swayed by an earthquake, the studio of the local station on the screen is not swaying), or by the presence of a response to the subtitle supermarket of the premature broadcast system (which sends information such as image/announcement based on the input to the computer, packet communication, etc.)

Peshawar (Pashto: , Urdu: ا ) is the capital of the Kaibal-Paktunkwa region of Pakistan, formerly the administrative center of the Tribal Tribal Area (FATA). It has a population of 197,000 (as of 2017). Peshawar means "High Fort" in Persian. In Japan, it is also referred to as Shockle or Peshawal. It is located 50 km to the west and is very close to the border with Afghanistan. Peshawar has a history of more ethnic control than in ancient times under the condition of just 50 km from the Kaibal Pass. In the 6th century BC, it was the first part of the Kingdom of Dhagan in the Kingdom of Haraghan, and in the period of 12th century it is said to have been a great place in the world of archaeology.

In the recorded history, the oldest city in Peshawar began with the construction of a "human city" in Sanskrit by the Kushana dynasty. Before the Kushana dynasty, Peshawar was believed to have been ruled by the Great Empire of Hakarmanish and Alexander III. Seleucus I, the diadocoe of Alexandrus III, was forced to withdraw from India. Peshawar was then ruled by the Mauritians, and Buddhism was introduced in the period of the Mauritians. The region, including Peshawar, was the king of the Kingdom of Greco-Bactarian Kingdom, Eucra Ides (9th place in BC), became the center of the Indo-Indo-Indo-Iranian period, when he was inhabited the center of India.

In April 2006, he became an honorary professor of the Department of Information Science, the Graduate School of Fine Arts and Information Sciences at the Graduate School of Fine Arts and Sciences. His father was born in Odo and his mother was also the eldest son of a successive medical family. Il dissoluto punito, ossia il Don Giovanni, K.527, is an opera buffa (or drama Jonathan) written by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart in 1787. The script was followed by Lorenzo da Ponte in Figaro. Don Giovanni is the protagonist of the story of the Spanish legendary libel Don van Don Fan. Mozart called the work "drama Jokoso" and it is said to have been a tragedy against the tragedyal drama of Jovances, but it is likely to have been influenced by some of her compositions, especially by Mozart's work, which she has been influenced by Morier's creation.

Ai-Khanoum (Ay Khanum) was an ancient Greek city in Tahar, northern Afghanistan, created in the 4th century BC after the conquest of Alexander III. It was identified by Alexandria on Oxus, and may later have been Eucratidia. The name "Ai-Khanoum" was a Uzbek word for "female of the moon." Oxus (the present-day Amdarya River) and the river Koccia (the site of the confluence of Alexandria on Oxus) were found at the site of the subcontinental frontier in India, and it was discovered by a French archaeologist during the first half of the 12th century.

Excavations were interrupted by the Afghan conflict, and the land became a battlefield, almost unreachable. There are several reasons why the city was built on this site. Due to its large riverside, agricultural irrigation waters were essential. The area from Ai Hanum to the Hindu Kush Mountains was rich in mineral resources, especially the "Rapislavi" produced from the Sali Sangu mine in the historic Badafshan (now Budahshan) region. There were also "ruby" (actually Spinel) and gold. It was also a location bordering with the area of northern nomads in Bactria, and was particularly important for trade with China. It was found that various crafts and crafts were found, and it was characterized by the high-level culture of the Greek city, which later became part of the Greek Empire.

India (Hindi: ) 2] or Republic of India (Hindi:  ) 3] is a federal republic located in South Asia that faces the Indian Ocean with most of the Indian subcontinent. The Barakzai Dynasty was a dynasty that existed in Afghanistan from the middle of the 19th century to 1973. The capital was Kabul. As Central Asia became a stage of confrontation between Russia and Britain (the Great Game), it fought against Britain three times, taking advantage of the conflict between the two (Afghan War; 1838 - 1842, 1878 - 1881, 1919) and secured independence and established the borders of present-day Afghanistan. The battle with foreign enemies also contributed to the formation of national consciousness of the "Afghan people." The Barakzai tribe of the Pashtoon Durani Federation (Barakzai) was the monarch, so it was called the Barrac Zay dynasty (1838 - 1878 - 1881, 1919). The name of the tribe was also derived from the name of the "Bahraqzai Dynasty" because of the name of the name of the tribe of the "Bahraqzai Dynasty".

The succession of the monarch by the descendants of Dost Muhammad ceased in 1929, and Muhammad Nadir Shah of the Musahiban family, the descendants of Dost Muhammad's younger brother, reestablished the kingdom. It is sometimes referred to as the Muhammadsay dynasty after 1929, or as the Muhammadian dynasty, and it is also distinguished from the Muhammadian dynasty. In this section, the dynasties of the Berakzay tribe, which continued from Dost Muhammad until the abolition of the monarchy in 1973, were referred to as the Berakzay dynasty. The monarch's title was Harn at the time of establishment in 1826, but changed to Amir (head) and Shah (head) in 1926.

The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

Molecular machines, or molecular machines, are molecules or molecular complexes that cause mechanical movements controlled by microscales or nanoscales. Largely speaking, there are biomolecular machines and synthetic (artificial) molecular machines. Biomolecular machines are proteins present in living organisms, also called molecular motors. certain functions are expressed by directional motions. Even if they are not molecular motors that cause relatively large motions, many enzymes exhibit functions by making conformational changes in a wide range of regions. Synthetic molecules are generally referred to as molecular machines that are organically synthesized, such as enzymes, or other proteins. Synthetic molecules are considered to be molecular machines that change their structure in response to photothermal, Hp, and oxidative reductions, and other external stimuli, such as those that change in the structure of nanomolecules. In the first place, many enzymes can be defined as molecular molecules.

At present, molecules with the property of being called molecular machines are often referred to as "molecular machines" (for example, when looking at a toluene of a liquid, the methyl group should be rotating against a benzene ring, but it is considered difficult to cause "meaningful" things such as rotating in one direction or changing the rotation on/off in response to stimuli. In this way, if the molecular motion is not controlled, it cannot be called molecular machines. In recent years, attempts have been reported to artificially control and utilize the functions of the ATP synthetase, adding artificial modifications to the above-mentioned ATP synthetase. Biomolecular machines have highly sophisticated movements and biological functions due to interactions between complexly shaped protein units. On the other hand, artificial molecular machines have a relatively simple structure because they are made organically, and they are practical, and can be called molecular machines without any progression.

A non-governmental organization is a mechanism and organization created by a private or private organization, both domestic and international. However, in English, NGOs are generally described as "NGOs" because they are considered to be countable nouns. The Rhine River Navigation Central Committee, established at the Vienna Conference in 1815, was limited to Central European countries, but in 1813 the Health Council included not only European countries, but also the Ottoman Empire. It was founded in the late 19th century by people who recognized that not only the safety and welfare of their own people, but also the joint welfare of their own countries, and that international cooperation was often gained by their own countries.

The Swiss Henri Dunnan, who witnessed the Battle of Solferino (1859) between Sardinia and France against Austria, wrote "Remembrance at Solferino" (1862), which led the Swiss government to organize an international conference aimed at improving the treatment of casualties, and in 1864 the Red Cross was organized in Geneva and privately. The governments that attended the meeting signed the Convention on the Treaty of the Convention of the Red Cross. The sanitation and health sectors were also set up in 1902. After World War I, the idea of reconsideration, such as the number of casualties, was regarded as an important issue, and the number of international federations was continued to increase in 1929. The number of organizations in the NGO organization was increased by 70%, and the number of non-profit organizations in the NGO community was increased by 70%.

The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

The Afghan Empire (Pashto:  اا اماي) or the Afghan Empire (Pashto:  ااا امي) was founded by Ahmad Shah Dullany, who ruled over the areas of present-day Afghanistan, Pakistan, northern Iran, eastern Turkmenistan, and northwestern India, including the Kashmir Valley. After the death of Nadir Shah in 1747, Ahmad Shah Dullany took control of the Kandahar region, where he began the conquest of Kabul, then Gadsney, and in 1749, he took control of the area of present-day Pakistan, northern Iran, eastern Turkmenistan, and northwestern India, including the Kashmir Valley. In 1747, Nadir Shah was forced to take control of the region of India, and he had already taken control of the area.

After the death of Ahmad in 1772, his son, Timur Shah, was enthroned as the new Dullanian ruler. Timur moved the capital to Kabul and established Peshawar as the winter capital. Ahmad Shah Dullani was considered as the foundation of the state in present-day Afghanistan, and was called the father of the people. In 1709, a coalition of Gilzai tribes led by Mirweis Hortak revolted against the Safavids in Kandahar and established the Safavid Empire in 1747, when his son, Hota Key, was elected to take control of the city in 1747.

The House of Saud (Arabic: الي al-Sudyaya, ل  l Sad, ل  l Sad, ل  l Sad, ل  l Sad, ل l Sad, ل l Sad) was the royal family of Saudi Arabia. The Saud family was originally a ruler of Diliyya in the middle of the Arabian Peninsula, which belonged to the Arab Muslim Sunnaan Aniza. In the mid-18th century, Muhammad ibn-Saud (he reigned: 1744 - 1765), who advocated the purification of Islam, joined forces with Muhammad ibn-Abdulławwayayayaya, who was the protector of herbs, and by the end of the 18th century it was the rulerdom of Egypt.

Later, Turky bin Abdullah moved to Riyadh to restore the Second Kingdom of Saud in 1824, but at the Battle of Mulayda (also known as the Royal Civil War) on January 24, 1891, Abdulphman bin Faisal Earl-Saud was deprived of the capital by the Lasede family, the ruler of northern Najud. Abdullahman bin Faisal Earl-Saud was exiled to Kuwait, and the Kingdom of Jabal Chambal ruled Najud.
