Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

People/Persons of Indian Origin (PIO) and non-resident Indians (NRIs, also known as NRIs/PIOs) are people of Indian descent living outside of India. Overseas Indians (NRIs) refer to foreign residents holding and acquiring Indian nationality, and Indian immigrants (PIOs) refer to those who have become non-Indian nationals and their descendants. In Japanese, the term "inkyo" is often used to refer to both of them. India is the world's largest sender of immigrants, and as of 2020, approximately 1787 million people and about 20,000 people (220,000 people) are working in the United Nations.

Although there is no clear definition, it is generally targeted at migrants from India since the 19th century. However, migrants from Pakistan and Bangladesh (both Muslims and Sunni migrants) separate from the British Indian Empire, as well as former British Sri Lanka (many upper-class Buddhists) are often included in the Indian race. Indo-American migrants are mostly British-dominated and migrated to English-speaking countries, which were British colonies around the world. In the 1830s, as migrant workers for the purpose of plantation sugarcane cultivation, they moved to areas such as Mauritius and Fiji in a single-year contract. However, at the time, India was a British colony, and many people were not able to return to the country even after the end of the contract. Others in the mid-19th century, during the period of Western supremacy in India, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and the United Kingdom of America and the United Kingdom of South Africa began to work as laborers for the purpose of cultivation of sugarcane in plantations.

The standard for writing on Wikipedia is not "whether it is true or not," but "whether it is verifiable." In other words, we provide Wikipedia with only "verifiable" content by referring to reliable sources (sources). This is called Verifiability (V). Verifiability is one of the three major policies regarding the content of Wikipedia. The other two are "neutral perspectives" and "no original research". Wikipedia determines the standard namespace, the type and quality of information that can be written on the article. These three policies are mutually complementary and should not be interpreted in a random manner. If the editors want to work on these three policies together, then they should not be discussed with each other. They should be discussed in a wide range of terms.

Having a good understanding of this is one of the most important secrets to writing a good article. Wikipedia aims to be a complete, trustworthy encyclopedia. When writing an article, it should be documented in reliable sources (e.g., magazines and newspapers with peer review systems) that can be verified by viewers and other editors. The verifiability in this context does not mean that editors are responsible for verifying, for example, whether or not the content of a New York Times article is true. In fact, editors are strongly asked to conduct that kind of investigation, because Wikipedia shouldn't publish their own research. Articles should include only those published by trusted sources. It doesn't matter if the individual editor thinks it's true or not. It doesn't seem like it's true, but it doesn't matter if it's true or not.

Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

The Alzakh Republic (Armenian:  , also known as the Nagolno-Karabakh Republic) is a de facto independent state located in Nagolno-Karabakh in South Caucasus. It is surrounded by Azerbaijan. The official language is Armenian, the currency is drums, and the capital is Stepanakelt. The Nagolno-Karabakh Autonomous Region, the territory of the Republic of the Republic of Azerbaijan, was established after the Nagolno-Karabakh War and the collapse of the Soviet Union declared independence. Joseph Robinette "Joe" Biden Jr. 2 (/bdn/; born November 20, 1942) is an American politician and lawyer, and the 46th President of the United States (born January 20, 1942), who became a Democrat, a member of the Newcastle County Legislature, a federal senator from Delaware, and a vice president at the age of 78 on January 20, 2021.

He became a lawyer in 1969, and was elected to the New Castle County Legislature in Delaware in 1970. He was elected to the Delaware Senate at the age of 29 in January 1973 and became the fifth youngest senator in the history of the United States. In December of that year, he lost his wife and daughter on Christmas shopping in a traffic accident. In June 1977, he remarried his current wife, Jill. From January 1973 to January 2009, he served in six consecutive terms as a federal senator, working on diplomacy, criminal justice and drug matters, and served as chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Senate Committee on Diplomacy. He established trust across the party as a coordinating politician who valued policy implementation. The Sakhalin dynasty (Persian: لل اا ) was a dynasty that existed mainly in the Siestern region (present-day Southeastern Iran, the state of Siestern Baluchestern and the south-eastern part of Afghanistan) and ruled the region from 861 to 1003. The Sakhalin capital was Zalange, located in present-day Afghanistan. The ruler of this dynasty was Yaacube ibn al-Rice al-Safferl, and the name of the dynasty was derived from his name. He was a coppersmith (Safferl) who had taken control of the Siestern region and conquered the eastern part of Afghanistan. He conquered the eastern part of Pakistan, which was now partly occupied by the eastern part of Afghanistan.

Higma (Ursus arctos, scientific name: Ursus arctos) is a mammal belonging to the family Ursus family. Along with polar bears, it has the largest body length in the family Kuma family. It is also the largest species in Japan's terrestrial mammals (including herbivore beasts). Ursus in the scientific name Ursus Arctos (Ursus arctos) is Latin for bears and arcos is Greek for bears ρ, which is Latin for bears. It is widely inhabited by Eurasian and North American continents from Europe to Asia. Its habitat ranges from temperate zones to the region of the Tundra climate (such as the Arctic Ocean coast) is the largest species in the United States. Ursus in the genus Ursus (Ursus arctos) is the most widely distributed subpopulation of the genus, which has been developed in the past 150 years and has been developed in the region of the Mediterranean.

The basal subspecies are Eurasian Higma (U. a. arctos). It is also called European Higma. It lives in Europe and West Siberia, but its main habitat is Russia. In many countries other than Russia, such as the extinction in the United Kingdom, the number of individuals has decreased sharply. In addition, there are a total of about 15 subspecies. The extinct subspecies are U. a. a. nelonionioni, U. a. californicus, and U. a. crowtheri, which lived around the Atlas Mountains along the northern Mediterranean of Africa in the 19th century. In the early 20th century, the largest species in the world, U. arowtheri, was one of the largest inhabitants in Japan.

The Mainichi Shimbun (formerly The Mainichi Shimbun) is one of the Japanese newspapers (national newspapers) published by the Daily Newspaper Company (owned by Daily Newspaper Group Holdings). It is counted as one of the three major newspapers along with Yomiuri Shimbun and Asahi Shimbun. It was the oldest newspaper in Japan and the Osaka Mainichi Shimbun and Tokyo Nikkashi Shimbun were the source. It was counted as two or more newspapers together with Asahi Shimbun before World War II, but due to the increasing competition and the management crisis caused by the Nishiyama Incident, sales of Yomiuri Shimbun continued to decline due to the increase in the number of newspapers issued by Yomiuri Shimbun in the late 1960s and early 1970s. In 2008, the issue of Dairy's New Wai Wai Wai newspaper, which was issued daily, was one of the most popular newspapers in Japan. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

The Korean aircraft YS-11 hijacking incident, which occurred on December 11, 1969, was hijacked by a South Korean intelligence officer in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea). This incident was the second political aviation incident in the history of the Republic of Korea after the revolt in 1958, and affected the response of South Korean authorities to the Yodo-go Hijack incident in 1970. It is said to have been the abducted incident by North Korea because some passengers were unable to return from North Korea after the incident. The incident resulted in the Japanese aircraft manufacturer leased to South Korea's former aircraft manufacturer YS-November, which was the second in the history of the Republic of the Republic of Korea (North Korea) in 1958. The incident affected the Korean government's response to the Yodo-go Hijack incident in 1970. It was also the case of North Korea's abducting abduction to takeover of the aircraft by the Korean authorities.

On the day after the incident, the North Korean authorities announced that "both pilots evacuated to North Korea" through a press conference of two pilots, claiming that it was "asylum" by the pilots. But in fact, it was an abduction operation by the North Korean intelligence department. According to the released passenger testimony and Korean authorities, the wolf of the North Korean spy who was sitting in the front seat as a passenger (at the age of 42 at the time) broke into the captain's room after taking off, and threatened to send a pistol to North Korea by the captain Yanagisu. The hostages, three North Korean fighters escalated from missionary to Pyongyang, were greeted by military personnel to arrive in Pyongyang, and 50 of the passengers, who had been detained by planes, were ordered to return to the United Nations to the United Nations as a secretariat in 1969.

The Afghan Peace Process (Afghan Peace Process) was a negotiation between the Taliban, the United States, and the Afghan government aimed at the ceasefire of the Afghan conflict and the reconstruction and peace of the future state. The peace negotiations with Taliban were long advocated by President Harmid Karzai and supported by the British and Pakistani governments, but the George W. Bush administration in the United States opposed it. In September 2007, he proposed peace to Taliban, but the Taliban immediately rejected it because of the presence of foreign forces. By 2009 the country's support for the end of the war was growing, but there was controversy about how it would become a major issue in the presidential election of Afghanistan. In January 2009, President Barack Obama became President of the United States, and the President of the United States of Afghanistan called for the re-election of President Barack Obama.

In May 2010, Carzai stated that the peace process for the future would be carried out with Taliban and other armed groups "not belonging to the al-Qaeda or other terrorist networks or ideological groups." Carzai also said, "Taliban is a country youth and hates the United States, and many of them would rather visit the United States to get a chance." One of Taliban's founders and deputy commander, Abdul Gani Baradard, was one of the leaders of a positive Taliban against dialogue with the United States and the Afghan government. However, in February 2010, Abdul was arrested by raids by American and Pakistani forces in Karachi, Pakistan. According to one theory, the president of Afghanistan was angrily angered at the meeting just before the arrest, and the government of Afghanistan was oppressed by the government of Afghanistan.

The COVID-19 pandemic (SARS-CoV-2) started at the end of 2019 and is a COVID-19 pandemic (global epidemic) that causes acute respiratory diseases and other diseases by using SARS coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) as a pathogen. Worldwide exposure to infectious diseases has led to a situation that humanity has not experienced in the past, such as global lockdowns, immigration restrictions, and postponement or reduction of international events. Due to this, the economic condition of the world has advanced, and online tourism, tourism, tourism, tourism, and tourism have become more and more and more urgent than ever.

Since SARS-CoV-2 is a research virus, it is unclear whether it can be treated like a normal cold even after the spread of the COVID-19 vaccine, and the situation continues to decline one by one. Long COVID, which may last for a long time, is also a concern. As of August 2022, infections have occurred in 230 countries and regions, with more than 600 million people infected and 6.4 million deaths. The Republic of Togo (French: République Togolaise) is a republic located in West Africa. It borders Benin to the east, Burkina Faso to the north, Ghana to the west, and the Gulf of Guinea to the Atlantic Ocean to the south. The capital is Lome. Togo is a tropical country south of Sahara and one of the countries with a turbulent history in the African continent. From the 11th to the 16th century, tribes invaded the region in various directions, and from the 16th century to the 18th century, the West African coast was a trade center in the purchase of European slaves, so the region and its surroundings were called "slave coasts" in 1884. Togo became a part of the French Republic of France, which was divided into two parts.

It is also a member of the Francophony International Organization, the United Kingdom and the Economic Community of West African States. Kandahar (Dalli: ا , translit. Qandahār) is a city in Afghanistan, the capital of Kandahar in the southern part of the country located in the Argandab River Valley. It has a population of 450,300 people (officially estimated in 2006) and is the second largest city in Afghanistan after Kabul. Its elevation is 1,005 m above sea level, 31°37′N 65°43’E. It is located in the Pashtun settlement area of the largest ethnic group in Afghanistan and is the main city of Pashtune alongside Peshawar, Pakistan. It is located on the route of the Asia Highway, on the north side of Tallin Court in Uruisgarn Province, and on the east side of the Khanny's, through which it passes through the Kabul and through the western part of Iran. It is also considered to be a major source of tobacco products in the Middle East.

In 1748, it was the capital of the Dullani dynasty founded by Ahmad Shah Dullany. It is also referred to as Kandahar. It is known that many people lived in Kandahar since prehistoric times and became the base of trade connecting India, Iran, and Central Asia. In the 6th century BC, the town of Candahar, now a part of the Persian Empire, became the Arracosia. The town of Kandahar, which was established in the 4th century BC and destroyed by the Akemenian king Alexander of Macedonia, was the chief priest of the region called the Arakosia region in Greek, and was built in the city of Alexandria, which had already been settled several thousand years ago, in the city of Kandahar. In the 5th century BC, the town of Arakosia became the province of Arakosia. The town of Kandahar, which was now connected to the Kingdom of Akemenia, was an imperial edict in the 4th century BC.

It is the only province in Iraq to face the sea (Persian Gulf). It borders the borders of Iran to the east and Kuwait to the south. The adjoining provinces three provinces: Mysarne to the north, Sicard to the northwest, and Mussanner to the west. When it was ruled by the Ottoman Empire, the area was called Basra Vilayet, and included the area that corresponds to the current Kuwait. In August 1990, however, the name was added to the name of the new province.

The Abbasid dynasty (Arabic: الل الاي ; الل الاي ) was the second Islamic dynasty of the Islamic Empire (750–1258), which ruled the Middle East region. It was established in place of the Umayya dynasty. It took the descendants of Abbas Ibn Abdulmthalib, the uncle of the founder of Islam Muhammad, as a caliph, and at its zenith its rule extended west from the Iberian Peninsula to Central Asia. In the Abbasid dynasty, Arab privileges were denied, equal rights were granted to all Muslims, and the golden age of Islam was established. The development of east-west agriculture and irrigation led to the prosperity of the Abbasid dynasty, which became the capital of the capital of Egypt, which became the predominant centre of modernism in the 9th century.

In 1055, it was under the protection of the Seljuks who destroyed the Bwich dynasty, but it was destroyed by the Mongol Empire in 1258. However, the Caliphate was protected by the Mamluk dynasty and survived until it was disbanded by Selim I of the Ottoman Sultan in 1518. The name "Islamic Empire" often refers to this dynasty in particular. Later, the Umayyad Empire and the Abbasid Empire were called the East Caliphate. At the end of the Umayyas, the privatization of the Islamists by the Umayya family was considered contrary to Allah's will written in Koran, and the faction of Muhammad's family was considered to be the leader of the Muslims religious group, and the Muslim movement was still extremistent and the Muslim movement was still in conflict with the Arabs.

Helmand (Dallie: لم ) is a state in southern Afghanistan with an area of about 58305 square kilometers (1st among 34 states), a total population of 879,500 (11th among 34 states), and a population density of 15 people/square kilometers (32th among 34 states). The capital is Rashkarger. Helmand is a state of about 90% of the northeastern region of Japan. The Helmand River, which runs north-south, is the longest river in Afghanistan, flows through the Hinduschshu Mountains and flows through the Hinduschsh River (11th out of 34 states), and the population density is sometimes referred to as Helmand County (32 out of 34 states). The capital is Rashkargar. Helmand is a state of about 90% of the northeastern part of Japan. The Helmand River, which flows north-sout of Helmand is the longest river in Afghanistan, flows along the Hinduschsch Mountains and flows into the southern part of the county.

At the time, the capital of the state was Bost, south of the current capital, but in about 1970 it moved to its current capital, Rashkarger. Bosto's name still appears to remain in the remains of the fortifications of QalaalaE-Bost, the University of Bosto, and the airport of Bosto. In the early 20th century, the state of Hermand was a dry wilderness that was not suitable for agriculture. However, in the state, the Helmando River, the largest river in Afghanistan, was thought to be capable of farmlanding if it could control the river. Before World War II, the Afghan government tried to develop the Helmando Valley with the help of Japan, Germany and the Soviet Union and the United States. At first, the two countries did not feel like they were developing the Helmando Valley. However, in the late 1950s, the state began full-fledged development under the cold war, with the development of Tennessee, and the construction of the Helmando River, which had been the largest river in Afghanistan, was expected to be built by the United States government.

Aizu Line is a railway line operated by Aizu Railway, which connects Nishiwakamatsu Station in Aizuwakamatsu City, Fukushima Prefecture and Aizu Takahara-Ozeguchi Station in Minami-Aizu-cho, Aizu County, Fukushima Prefecture. Aizu Line was originally operated by Aizu Railway Co., Ltd., which became a local line of the Japan National Railways (JNR) and became a line of the East Japan Railway Company (JR East) due to the division and privatization of Japan National Railways in April 1987, and then, in July of the same year, it was converted into a line of the Third Sector Railway (JR East) and became a line of the Aizu Railway. The operation system of the Aizu Railway is divided into the following two sections due to the existence or absence of electrification and direct operation. Both stations are connected by Aizu Takahara-Ozeguchi Station or Aizudashima Station. The operation period of the entire line is approximately one hour long, and the operation period of each section of the train is operated by the Aizu-Takahara-Ozeguchi Station or the Ai-Tateshima Station, and the trains are operated by the Aizu-Tetsu Railway Company, which is operated by the Aizu-Takatsu Railway, which is operated by the Aizu-Takamatsu Railway, which is operated by the Aizu-Takatsu Railway, which is operated by the Aichi-Takamatsu Railway, and is operated by the Aizu-Takamatsu Railway.

At present, this line is one section of the main route from the Tokyo area to the Aizu region, such as Asakusa Station, but due to the fact that it took over the existing Kunitetsu Aizu Line (between Nishiwakamatsu Station and Aizutajima Station), trains bound for Aizuwakamatsu Station bound for the south were treated as trains bound for Aizuwakamatsu Station, trains bound for Aizuwakamatsu Station were treated as trains bound for the north, and trains numbered as trains bound for Aizuwakamatsu Station were basically odd numbers for trains bound for Aizuwakamatsu, and trains bound for Aizutashima Station were given even numbers for trains bound for Aizutashima Station, while trains operated on the Noiwa Railway and Higashi Railway (currently only the Tobu 500 Series train) were operated, on the contrary, trains bound for Asakusa and Kirikawa Onsen Hot Springs Station to Tsudashima Station were treated as trains bound for Aizuwakamatsu Station, and trains numbered as trains bound for Aizuwakamatsu Station, and trains bound for Aizudashima Station were changed to those bound for Aizutashima Station; however, trains operated on the Noiwa Railway and Higashi Railway (currently, only the Tobu 500 Series) trains were changed to those operated at the same time.

The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

Earthquakes are used in the following two ways. Earthquakes specialize in earthquakes are called seismology. seismology is a field of geophysics. The ground bedrock is subjected to force (strains) due to various factors, and earthquakes are caused by rapid deformation. a kind of geological phenomenon (geological activity) that occurs inside the earth. the phenomenon that changes the crust very slowly in response to an earthquake is called crustal fluctuation. the cross section of a rock that is deformed by an earthquake is often called a fault, and it does not reach the surface of the ground at a depth of several miles to several tens of kilometers, but at the time of a large earthquake, the end of which appears on the surface of the earth and becomes the surface of the ground. It is thought that once the surface of the earthquake is repeatedly deteriorating due to the intensity of the earthquake. It is thought that the earthquake occurs repeatedly in Japan.

The vibration generated by an earthquake is a high-speed earthquake wave that travels through the ground and feels like an earthquake movement on the surface of a human being. Seismic waves are a kind of wave, and are roughly divided into waves transmitted in the ground (substantial waves) and waves transmitted on the surface (surface waves). In addition, real waves are divided into fast P-waves (threshold waves) and slow S-waves (horizontal and twisted waves). The fine seismic motions (early microtremors) that are often felt at the beginning of an earthquake are caused by P-waves and severe earthquakes (main motions) of earthquakes (mainly by S-waves). P-waves and S-waves are mainly different in speeds, so that they can be detected at an initial time of the difference in the time of arrival of the P-wave and S-waves. In spite of the fact that they can be detected at a longer distance from the initial source of earthquakes, they can be used to detect earthquakes.

Protectorate (French: protectorat, English: protectorate) is a country that receives protection from a country by substituting a portion of its sovereignty based on a treaty. Protected states may be referred to as protected states, or protected countries may be referred to as protected countries. The concrete content is generally interpreted by a treaty between the protected countries and the protected countries, but as a general rule, if it is not stated to be a case to be handled by the protected countries, the authority of the protected countries is left as a general rule. In particular, some of the external powers are allowed to be exercised by the protected countries. In most cases, protection relations are set between states with different powers, so it is often concluded in the form of being pushed to the protected countries. In addition, if the target country does not exist, it is often referred to as a "protected State" (also referred to as the "Provincial Property" in French, etc.)

The concept of protection is quite old, and it has already appeared in the book About Obligation by the Roman politician Marcus Tullius Cicero. In it, Cicero says that the Senate is not the ruler of Rome, but the "patrocinium" of the whole world. Rome has a large number of territories and provinces, and Cicero is considered to have defined this relationship. A similar relationship is pointed out between Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte and the monarchs of the Rhine allies. Napoleon declared that "the monarchs do not have a head of the sect" and appealed that it is not a subordinate relationship. The concept of protection was first introduced in Japan. The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

The Tokaido New Line was a new railway that was planned to be constructed next to the Tokaido Main Line, parallel to or close to the Tokaido Road. It is also called the Shin-Tokaido Line. As it was called the Tokaido Megaropolis in later years, major cities were concentrated in the vicinity of the Tokaido Road, so a number of plans were made to build the Tokaido Main Line in the future because the amount of transportation increased and the Tokaido Main Line became insufficient. First of all, there was a call for private railways to build the second main line in the Meiji period. It was applied as the Japan Electric Railway in the Meiji period. However, because major railways were subject to the national policy by the Railway National Law, the construction of the Tokaido Main Line had not been carried out, this plan was not realized until the end of the period when the Tokaido Main Line was established in the same year as Nagoya-1927, when the Tokaido Main Line was inaugurated.

However, due to the Great East Japan Depression, the extension of the Tokaido Nishinsen Line to Shizuoka Prefecture using the Tosan Railway License was not realized, and the section of the Tokaido Nishinsen Line ceased to be opened. Although the Shinkeihan Railway, which built the Kyoto Main Line of the Hankyu Railway, was planned to extend to Nagoya along the Tokaido Road (later changed to a route via Ishizuchi), it was not realized. The Daitetsu Group, such as the Osaka Electric Tramway and the Sannomiya Express Railway, which were predecessors of the Kinki Nippon Railway, had completed the Nasaka Line via Hatsuse-kaido Road at the beginning of the Sino-Japanese War, but it was thought that Hijiro INOUCHI, the superintennisor of the Sangukyu Railway, and the Sangukyu Railway merged to form the Kansai-kyusen Railway Company, and other companies such as Torata, had acceded to the new section of the Tosen Line after the end of the war.

Gandahāra (Chinese: 健, ; pinyin: Gandhāra; pinyin: Gāndhāra) was an ancient kingdom in the northwestern part of Pakistan that prospered around the capital Bakram. It was located on the north bank of the Kabul River and reached the border of the Kashmir Valley across the Indus River. The Kingdom of Gandhāra lasted from the 6th century BC to the 11th century BC, and in the 1st to the 5th century it reached its peak under the Kshanas, who believed in Buddhism. After being conquered by the Gaznas Sultan Mahmoud in 1021, the name of Gandahra was lost. Under the rule of Islam, the region of Kahra was known as the Kashmir Valley.

Depending on the period, the Peshawar Valley, the Taxilla and the Swart Valleys were included in the Gandara territory, but the center was always in the Peshawar Valley. The capital of the kingdom was located in Charsada, Taxilla, Peshawar, and at the end of the year in Indus Hunt. The name of Gandara appeared in Rig Veda, but it was known in the 6th century BC that it was incorporated into the prints by King Persiaculus of the Akemenes, or by King Darius I of Persepolis, and the inscription "GADARA" was recorded in the inscription of King Charles I of Persepolis. The history of the Greek historians in the 20th century was dominated by the king of Persepolis.

The tunnel was completed after two major flooding accidents during construction and was completed due to two major route changes. As a result of the change in the route, a curve with a radius of 1,500 m occurred in the tunnel, the operation speed of Shinkansen at 240 km/h was forced to slow down to 160 km/h when passing through the curve part of the tunnel. The new Austrian Tunnel Tunnel (NATM) was adopted for the first time in Japan. The tunnel was used for the first time during the construction period of construction that exceeded its original expectations, and was delayed during the construction period during which construction was delayed, and the entire route was completed. As for the route of the Joetsu Shinkansen line in Gunma Prefecture, it was not a route along the Tone-gawa River, like the Joetsu Line, but rather a tunnel running through the Takahara area at the west side of the moon and night, which was approached, was selected by the lower tunnel of the Takahara area around the time of the time, and it was said that there was an opinion that there was a plan to make good use of the Nakayama Tunnel.

The Tibetan Okura-kyo Sutra was a collection of Tibetan Buddhist scriptures compiled mainly by translating Sanskrit Buddhist scriptures into Tibetan since the end of the 8th century. It contains many translations of late Buddhist scriptures that were eventually lost and dispersed in India, and its translation work has been constantly verified and re-translated by careful revision work for many years, so that if there is no Sanskrit original text, it is more reliable than the study of Buddhist scholars around the world by estimating the original text, such as translating it backwards from Tibetan translations. The first part of Tibetan was written in the 7th century itself, in which the vomited Song btsan gampo was gampo in 1963, and the second half of the 2nd century was written in Tibetan.

Later, the former became the Zerpa book and the latter became the Shar book. In Tibet, the scriptures were promulgated in manuscripts with faith, but in the Ming dynasty of China, the Emperor Eiraku, as a souvenir to Tibetan princes and sects sending envoys to China, opened the Okura-kyo Sutra in 1410, this custom was incorporated into Tibet, and several versions have since been opened. The oldest edition of Tengule was the Yosei edition (1724) and the Nartan edition (1742) was also written by Chungche-bon, which supplemented the Shale book. The Delgae edition (1742) also refers to the same book, which was published in 1732, and the other editions of Tengule were published in 1737.

In molecular biology, messenger ribonucleic acid, also known as mRNA or messenger ribonucleic acid, is a single-strand ribonucleic acid (RNA) molecule corresponding to the gene sequence of the gene, and is read by ribosomes in the process of synthesizing proteins. mRNA is created in the process of transcribed by an enzyme called RNA polymerase that converts the gene into an mRNA precursor (pre-mRNA) of a primary transcript. This pre-mRNA usually contains the region of intron that does not encode the final amino acid sequence. These are removed in the process of RNA splicing, leaving only Exxon, the region that encodes the protein. This exon sequence is composed of RNA. The maturation mRNA, which is then read by the mRNA, is produced in the process of producing a sequence of RNAs.

Each codon codes a specific amino acid, but a terminating codon that stops protein synthesis is an exception. To translate from codon to amino acid, two types of RNA are required: metastasis RNA that recognizes codons and supplies corresponding amino acids, and ribosomal RNA (rRNA), a central component of the protein manufacturing equipment contained in ribosomes. The concept of mRNA was developed in 1960 by Sydney Brenner and Francis Crick (see history). During the process of experimentation, François Jacob and Jack Monou created the name "messenger RNA." In 1961, James Watson's research team and mRNA was isolated by Jacob, Mono, and Messselson, and mRNA was described as an independent mRNA, and mRNA was described as an independent mRNA. The Neolithic period, which is said to have started with the development of cultivation in the form of the Neolithic Revolution, is traditionally the last part of the Stone Age. As the name suggests, it belongs to the Holocene as a definition, and it is not necessarily associated with the beginning of well-crafted hammers and polished stone tools. However, it is assumed that it is the beginning of agriculture and ranching in Western Asia, Europe and China, and the oldest one can be traced back to 8000 BCE, but from 6000 BCE to 5000 BCE to the end of 5000 BCE. In the Americas, it can be seen directly from the 4000 BCE to the 4000 BCE to the Andes Mountains, etc., the beginning of agriculture can be seen directly from the 4000 Bronze Age to the 5000 Bronze Age. However, it is not possible to obtain metal in the 6th century.

In the so-called Old World regions of Europe, West Asia, and North Africa, a systematic study of the Neolithic period is progressing. The Neolithic culture appears in Levant (Ellico, Palestine) around 8500 BC. The region developed directly from the sub-lithic Natuf culture. Natuf culture pioneered the use of wild grains, which can be called the Proto Neolithic period (circa 11000 BC - around 8500 BC). Natuf culture people began to rely on wild grains to settle, so climate changes associated with Yangartlias forced the development of agriculture. During the 8500 BC, the population of Natuf culture was made up of crops, cereals, cereals, and cereals.

The Republic of Guinea, also known as the Republic of Guinea, is a republic in West Africa, bordered by Senegal to the north, Guinea-Bissau to the northwest, Mali to the northeast, Sierra Leone to the south, Liberia to the south, and Cote d'Ivoire to the south, and facing the Atlantic Ocean to the west. The capital is Konacule. Among the former French colonial empires, it was one of the states that was independent by referendum in 1958, ahead of other colonies. The official name was République de Guinée in French, and it was called Guinée. The official English name was Republic of Guinea of Guinea, and the official name was "Republic of Guinea of Guinea" (Guinea of Guinea), and it was also referred to as "Republic of Guinea" in 1984.

When the Kingdom of Ghana was destroyed in the 12th century, the Sioux established the anti-Islamic Kingdom of Susuo, against the Berber-Islamic Mlavites. The FIFA Women's World Cup, hosted by the International Football Federation (FIFA), is a women's World Cup competition hosted by the National Football Federation. The "World Cup" part is sometimes described as "W Cup." It is described as the "FIFA Women's World Cup" year with the host country and year. Since the first tournament in 1991, it has been held once every four years, and the tournament takes about one month. The national football association's team is also called the women's national team and women's national team, and the team who won the qualifying tournament will gradually compete in the tournament until the first sixteenth tournament in 1995.

Until the 3rd FIFA Women’s World Championship in 1999, the FIFA Women’s World Cup was named after the 4th FIFA Women’s World Cup in 2003. It was held eight times by December 2021, and the winners were in the United States (1991, 1999, 2015 and 2019), Norway (1995), Germany (2003, 2007) and Japan (2011). The first FIFA World Cup was held in China in 1991. The 12 countries participated in the tournament and the United States became the first champion. The 2nd tournament was held in Sweden and Norway won in 1995. The 3rd U.S. Championship was held in the 3rd World Cup in the United States (USA) and more than 186 million people were seen in China.

JR (an abbreviation for Japan Railways) is a unified general term for a railway company established in 1987 by the division and privatization of Japan National Railways. In the JR Group, there are six passenger business companies and one freight business company, a company responsible for railway research institutes (public interest foundations) and computer systems, and there are companies responsible for railways and freight companies, which are affiliated with other companies, such as JR Corporation, which are affiliated with a number of companies, including JR Corporation, which are affiliated with a number of companies.

A seismometer is a device for measuring a tremor at the time of an earthquake. A seismometer is a device for measuring and recording the tremors generated by an earthquake (the motion of the ground). However, the purpose of observation is to measure two earthquakes, one or more than one or more. seismometers can be used to measure the tremortality of the tremortem.

The Japan Meteorological Agency gathers the information of seismometers installed in various places, determines the time of earthquake and the source of earthquakes, and calculates the magnitude. Nur Muhammad Taraki (Pashto:  مم  ; June 15, 1917 – October 8, 1979) was an Afghan politician, president of the first revolutionary council of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan. He was born a wealthy farmer in the village of Karay, Nawa County, Gazney. He graduated from an elementary school in Mukul and attended a night English school in Bombay. He received a bachelor's degree at the University of Carble, a master's degree at Columbia, and a doctorate at Harvard. In 1932, he was hired by a fruit exporter in Kandahar. He was promoted to secretary of the Bombay City Branch for his excellent work. In Bombay, he became a citizen of the Pathuan Nationalist Abdul-Hurgh, a member of the Federal Republic of Bombay, where he began writing newspapers for the first time since 1952.

In 1953, he held a press conference in New York, where he said, "The current system is oppressive, authoritarian, and does not change in place of one of the kings." The American press reported that he would be politically exiled to Britain, but he returned to his country. From 1955 to 1958, he interpreted American foreign missions; from May 1962 to September 1963, he founded the U.S. Embassy in Afghanistan; and in 1963, he first visited the Soviet Union and was recognized as a progressive activist by the Soviet Communist Party. On January 1, 1965, the People's Democratic Party's First Establishment Conference was held in Kabul to elect the Secretary-General and Executive Committee. Although he ran for election from his home village to Congress, the People's Party of Afghanistan (Afghanistan) between May 1962 and September 1963, the People's Party of Afghanistan and the People's Party (Pulchalm) split into two groups, the People's Party and the People's Party.

The United States Department of State (DOS) is one of the administrative bodies of the United States. It implements foreign policy and is equivalent to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of other countries. Under the Secretary and Deputy Secretary, there is an Under Secretary for each field and an Assistant Secretary for each field. There are approximately 5,000 staff members in the United States alone. There are two vice-presidents from the Barack Obama administration inaugurated in 2009 and one is responsible for the overall diplomatic policy and the other is responsible for managing the organization within the Department. The Department of State appreciates the President’s advice on the formulation and implementation of the U.S. foreign foreign policy, as well as the United States’s foreign policy and other policies, which are responsible for foreign policy development and implementation of the United States of America, as well as the United States of America and the United States of Americas, as the United States of Americas.

The State Department has more than 250 diplomatic and consular agencies around the world. In 1999, the State Department merged the Military Disarmament Authority and the U.S. Intelligence Agency into the Department's organization and duties. In 1788, the U.S. Constitution granted the President diplomatic powers. On July 21, 1789, the U.S. Senate and Senate passed a bill for the establishment of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. President George Washington signed it on July 27, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs became the first federal agency under the new constitution. In September of the same year, the Ministry changed its name to the Department of State and assigned various internal administration duties. The administration of the United States Mint, the United States National Statistics, and most of the administration of the United States of America, and the rest of the House of Representatives of the United States, were replaced by the President of the United States.

The section was operated from Shinmaebashi Station to Takasaki Station on the side of Gunma Prefecture, and therefore, the section between Oyama Station and Takasaki Station was introduced as a double-floor line. In order to guide passengers, the section between Oyama Station and Takasaki Station in the southwestern part of Tochigi Prefecture and the east part of Gunma Prefecture and the east part of the eastern part of Gunma Prefecture were connected with each other, and the section of the Tobu Line was used for the purpose of commuting.

On the other hand, the Ryoge Line is mainly used for regional transportation along the line, and the majority of the trains are local trains. Mini-Pattai" in 1991, and since then, he has been working in various genres such as comedy, violin and horror. Wáng Y (Chinese: ; pinyin: Wáng Y; born October 19, 1953) is a politician and diplomat in the People's Republic of China. He is a member of the State Council for Diplomatic Affairs in charge of Diplomatic Affairs and the 11th Department of Diplomatic Affairs. He served as Chairman of the Six-Party Meeting, Vice-Minister of Diplomatic Affairs, 17th, 18th, 19th Party Central Committee, Ambassador to Japan, and Chief of the State Council's Taiwan Office. He was an honorary doctor of the 35th Department of Foreign Affairs at Ritsumeikan University. He was fluent in Japanese and English and often held meetings and lectures with Japanese counterparts in Japanese. He was born on October 19, 1953 in Beijing, Beijing. After graduating from high school in 1969, he went on to study as a member of the Department of Foreign Affairs at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan, and returned to Japan in September, 1989.

In 1997, he became a visiting researcher at Georgetown University. In 1998, he successively held the position of Vice-Minister of State (Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs). During his arbitration, he signed a memorandum of understanding with Japan concerning the former Japanese military abstinence chemical weapons on July 30, 1999. In September of the same year, he majored in international relations at the Institute of Diplomatic Studies and obtained a doctorate. In March 2001, he became the chief of China during the three-member consultations of the United States, China and North Korea. On August 27 of the same year, he served as the host of the first six countries of Japan and Russia held talks in Beijing, and served as chairman of the fourth meeting in which the military power was exchanged. In September of the same year, he was elected as the Vice-Minister for Foreign Affairs of Asia (Secretary-General of Foreign Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs) in March of the United States, China and North Korea. On August 27, 2003, he was elected as China's senior vice-president for foreign affairs.

Shinkansen Series 700 (Shinkansen Series 700) is the fourth generation Shinkansen train for the Tokaido and Sanyo Shinkansen that belongs to the Tokaido Railway Company and the West Japan Railway Company. In order to speed up the entire Tokaido and Sanyo Shinkansen line with reasonable manufacturing and maintenance costs, JR Tokaido and JR West developed it jointly in the fall of 1997, and after 16 prototype cars were completed and various tests were conducted, the operation started in 1999. The maximum speed was 285 km/h. In addition, 7000 cars specialized for the Sanyo Shinkansen line were introduced in and out of Japan in 2000. The manufacture of the Japanese car, Hitachi Kasasaki Works, and the 1300-Year-Origin-Original Company was not named in accordance with the name of the above-mentioned designation, but the name of the car was originally used in the form of JR Generation 1300.

In the case of the C-organization ordered by JR Tokai and the B-organization and E-organization ordered by JR West, there are differences centered on the running equipment. Details are described in each section. The car body is made of aluminum alloy and has a double-skin structure with interlocking soundproofing materials. The structure is lightweight and low-cost while taking into account the noise inside the car. The normal car's side-window dimensions are 590 mm x 700 mm in width and 710 mm in height, the same as that of the 300 series. The cross-section of the car is narrowed from the top of the window to the roof, and this is related to the height of the guest door window. The leading shape is characterized by the unique shape of an air flow type that is similar to that of the 500 series, in order to realize the countermeasure against tunnel micro-pressure waves with a short nose. In the case of the first part of the car, the cross-sectional section of the car is narrowed from the top of the window to the roof. Since 1815, the first part of the car is connected to the first part of the car.

Shunzetsu (Simplified Chinese: 春; traditional Chinese: 春節 音: Chnjié Chunchie; note: ) is the New Year's Day (old New Year's Day) of the old calendar in China and China. It is considered to be the most important national holiday in China, and it is celebrated grandly compared to the New Year's Day in the new calendar, and it is set for several days in nine countries and regions such as China and Singapore. In this section, it mainly refers to the New Year's Day as the old New Year's Day in China, and the old New Year's Day in other regions refer to the item of the old New Year's Day in China. In the case of spring festival, the old New Year's Day in China, the old New Year's Day in China, and the old New Year's Day in China is mixed with the old calendar in China. In the case of the old calendar, the first day of the New Year's Day in China, the first day of the New Year's Day is the first day of the New Year's Day in China.

Also, because it is the beginning of the year, month, and day, it is sometimes called 'Sancho' because it is the first morning of each of them. In ancient China, rituals for ancestors and goddesses were held at the beginning of the end of the year, and it was common to pray for good harvest. In "Shokyo" (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), it is written that Confucianism led the subjects to enshrine heaven in the New Year. According to legend, the date of New Year's Day differed depending on the dynasties, and the New Year's Day in the summer calendar was considered to be the New Year's Day in the summer calendar, and the New Year's Day in the summer calendar was considered to be the New Year's Day in the Sui period, and the month of November in the New Year's Day in the Sui period was called the New Year's Day in the Sui Dynasty, and the month of October in the era of the Sui Dynasty was designated as the New Year's Day in the New Year's Day.

Gross National Product (GNP) is a total value-added product (product) or service newly produced by a national for a certain period of time. It was used frequently in newspapers and textbooks to compare the size of the country's economy, but in Japan, national gross production (GDP) has been used as a representative indicator since 1993, and it has become less noticeable. In 2000, the concept of gross national production itself has disappeared due to changes in the system of national economic calculations. However, the new system has almost the same concept of gross national income (GNI). "Total gross national production" is an economic concept that targets the subject of the country and does not have any nationality. In the case of individuals, it has not been worth more than two months living in the territory of the country.

Another flaw is the good and bad of increasing the output of goods and services (e.g., the building boom caused by the earthquake and the building boom that is not the same as the building boom). In general national production (GNP), which is based on the concept of "national" that targets the inhabitants of the country, has a domestic gross domestic production (GDP), which is based on the concept of "domestic" that is the economic entity that resides in the country. The difference between real GNP and actual GDP is small and the same trend. The national gross domestic production (GDP) has become more important than the national gross national production (GNP) as an indicator of the country's economic activity. In the 1980s, gross national production has been considered to be a beneficial indicator for determining the country's economic activity, but it has been considered to contribute to overseas activities through foreign investment since the 1980s. The concept of gross national production itself has been adopted as an alternative to the national economy.

Fujikichiro KINOSHITA → Hideyoshi KINOSHITA → Hideyoshi HASHIBA Toyotomi Hideyoshi (Hideyoshi KINOSHITA/Hideyoshi KINOSHITA) was a Japanese military commander from the Sengoku period (period of warring states) to the Azuchi-Momoyama period, a daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period (period of warring states). Tenkajin (the first) and a chief adviser to the warlord of the samurai family, Uzumasa, who succeeded Nobunaga ODA and established the foundation of a feudal society in the early-modern period. Yaemon KINOSHITA's childhood name was Hiyoshimaru KINOSHITA (Tokichiro KINOSHITA), who was a son of Nakamura Owari (Nakamura), and he gradually succeeded Nobunaga MATSUKASHITA, who was a man under Nobunaga MATSUSHITA's command in the battle, and became a leader in the battle of the Battle of Oga-no-no-no-no-no-kami.

He became Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) and Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state) and was given the surname of Toyotomi by the Imperial Court. He defeated Yoshihisa SHIMAZU, conquered Kyushu, established the government, issued the order to kill swordsmanship and to stop pirates. He defeated the Hojo clan, conquered Kanto and Ou, and unified the whole country. He promoted the integration of the country with many policies across the country, such as Taikokenchi, Tsurugi-rei, Kotogi-rei, and Ishidakasei. On the basis of his strong power and financial base, he also started building luxurious buildings such as Jurakudai and Hoko-ji Daibutsu (Great Buddha of Kyoto) and contributed to the development of Momoyama culture. In his later years, he decided to conquer the Ming Dynasty and dispatched troops to Korea (the Bunroku-Keicho War), but he was well aware of the fact that he did not have any knowledge of his father's history until Hideyoshi's death.

Nagano Station is a station of the East Japan Railway Company (JR East), Shino Railway Co., Ltd. and Nagano Electric Railway Co., Ltd. (Nagano Electric Railway) located in Oaza-Awata and Minami Chitose-chome, Nagano City, Nagano Prefecture. It is the central station of Nagano City, the prefectural capital of Nagano Prefecture, and it is the largest terminal station in the prefecture. It has an elevation of 361 m. The Hokuriku Shinkansen Line is the end point of 'Ama' and all trains of 'Kagayaki' and 'Hakutaka' stop at this station. The office code of JR Nagano Station is 511114. The train line of the Hokuriku Shinkansen Line and Shinetsu Main Line of JR East Japan, which is located on the north side of the Shinetsu Main Line, and the Nagano Electric Railway Line of the Nagano Line is the last stop of the Hokurikuno Line, and the train of the Hokurikuno Line is the same as that of the JR Hokurikuriku Line.

Both lines were originally part of the Shinetsu Main Line, and this station was an intermediate station of the Shinetsu Main Line. As a result of the business separation of the parallel existing line following the opening of the Hokuriku Shinkansen, the section of the Shinano Railway Line was transferred on October 1, 1997, and the section of the Kitashina Line was transferred due to the extension of the line on March 14, 2015 and became the current form. Nagano Station is essentially the terminal station of the Saganoi Line. For long-distance transportation, the limited express "Shina" connecting the station to Nagoya Station from the start of the train, the rapid "Misuzu" connecting from Okadani Station to Iida Station on the Iida Line, and the temporary rapid "scape resort" connecting the Oito Line to Minami-Odani Station has been remodeled, and the platform of the Shinkansen Line will be opened at the end of the Saganoi Line. The Republic of Senegal (French: République du Sénégal epyblik dy seneal), commonly known as the Republic of Senegal, is a republic located at the south-west end of the Sahara Desert in West Africa. It borders Mauritania in the northeast, Mali in the east, Guinea in the southeast, Guinea-Bissau in the south, and Gambia in the south. It is also bordered by the gambia, which has a long shoreline of the Gambia River, and Senegal surrounds the country from land. The region of Casamans in the south of Senegal is separated from the rest of the region. The region faces the Atlantic Ocean, and borders of Bobel and the sea are bordered to the south. The term "Senegal" was used to refer to as the capital of France.

The official name is French, République du Sénégal, commonly known as Sénégal. The official English notation is Republic of Senegal snl, -l. The Japanese notation is the Republic of Senegal, commonly known as Senegal. The remains of the Paleolithic and Neolithic periods have been found and have been inhabited by mankind since the middle of the Senegal River, the lower part of the Senegal River since the 9th century. The Kingdom of Ghana, the Kingdom of Technology Rule (Tucrol, 1285 - 1485), and especially in the late 1434s, the name of the Kingdom of Armenia was used to refer to the influence of the Kingdom of the Kingdom of Armenia.

Shinji SOGO (April 14, 1884 - October 3, 1981) was a railway official and politician in Japan. He was born in Nakamura, Shingun, Ehime Prefecture (Nakatsuki-cho, present-day Niihama City) from 1945 to 1946, and was the fourth president of the Japan National Railways (JNR) from 1955 to 1963. He was appointed as the "Father of the Shinkansen" (Shinkansen) and was appointed as the first honorary citizen of Saijo City. In 1884, he was born in Nakamura, Shingun (Nakatsuki-cho, present-day Niihama City) in Ehime Prefecture as the second son of Nabe-zukuri and Sou in 1897, and was appointed to a preparatory high school at the University of Tokyo during the Meiji period of high school and was appointed as a preparatory high school in 1898.

Shinpei GOTO, who was the president of the Railway Academy at that time, advocated the change of course to standard gauge, and with Yasujiro SHIMA and others to realize the plan, he influenced the Shinkansen concept later. In 1917, he studied in the United States for a year for railway inspection, and he realized the difference in national strength with the United States and felt the need for cooperation between Japan and China in order to avoid war. He mainly went through the accounting field and became the head of the Accounting Department at the young age of 36. After that, he went to the Teito Revival Office with Kiyoshi KANAI and Kozo OTA, who were established for the reconstruction of the Great Kanto Earthquake, and, together with Goto, he was charged with bribery and bribery related to land buying and selling (a suspicious of the Rehabilitation Bureau), and was arrested in the first case. In 1930, however, he was sentenced to death.

The Hokuetsu Express Hokuhoku Line is a railway line operated by the Hokuetsu Express Co. , Ltd. , starting from Rokkaicho Station in Minami-Uonuma City, Niigata Prefecture, and connecting to Niigata Station in Kamikoshi City, Niigata Prefecture. It was built in 1968 as a scheduled line of the Japan National Railway (National Railways) that has a short circuit line to the Hokuriku area, and it started operation on March 22, 1997 by the Hokuetsu Express. Since its opening, trains that contact with the Joetsu Shinkansen have been operated, and until the extension of the Hokuriku Shinkansen line between Nagano Station and Kanazawa Station on March 14, 2015 has been operated as the main route connecting the Tokyo metropolitan area and Hokurikuriku.

In many countries, January 1st is regarded as a public holiday. In Japan, it has been regarded as one of the four major festivals (Kigen-setsu, Shiho-setsu, Tencho-setsu and Meiji-setsu) called Shiho-setsu after Shiho-hai, an Imperial family event from the Meiji period to the early Showa period. According to Article 2 of the Act on National Holidays promulgated and enforced (Act No. 178 of July 20, 1948), Shiho-setsu became a national holiday with the aim of "celebrating the beginning of the year" on behalf of Shiho-setsu. From January 1 to January 3 of the New Year's Day (three days) or "Matsunouchi" Note 1 of the New Year's Day, in various places in Japan, especially in the New Year's Day's Day, the New Year's Day was held every year, and the first day of the New Year's Day was held in the 12th century.

The Republic of the Sudan (Arabic: مي الا ), commonly known as the Republic of the Sudan, is a republic located in Northeast Africa. The capital is Hartoum. It is located in Egypt in the north, Chad and Central Africa in the west, Ethiopia in the south, Ethiopia in the southeast and Eritrea in the east. The eastern side faces the Red Sea and Saudi Arabia on the opposite side. Before the separation of the Republic of the Congo from the Republic of Africa in July 2011, it had a total area of 2505,813 square kilometres and was the largest continent in Africa.

As a nation, Sudan occupies the eastern part of Sudan, historically known as East Sudan. After the independence of South Sudan, it is rare to refer to the Republic of Sudan as "North Sudan", but it is often referred to as "North Sudan" in terms of bilateral relations. The northern part of the Nile basin of Sudan, formerly known as Nubia, was strongly influenced by ancient Egypt, which flourished in the north. The ancient Egyptian dynasties made their way south along the Nile, forming gold and ivory trading bases, and then retreated as the power declined. Around 2200 BC, a group of blacks migrated from the South became known as the Kingdom of Kushshu, and the kingdom of Egypt, which later became the Kingdom of Egypt.
